Entry.1:
1917.

Volunteered for the Australian Camel Field Ambulance for service abroad. 

Went through oral examination for same, and 
were
was inspected by Capt. J. A. Heath, who is making the selection for this unit that is 
supposed 
to sail on
Entry.3:
1917.

Notified that I have been accepted for A.C.F.A. and to be sent on final leave tomorrow morning
Entry.4:
1917.

Returned from final leave and underwent a
n
 medical exam for embarkation.
Entry.5:
March1917.

(Official word of embarkation announced to us at 5 p.m. for
Entry.6:
and to move out of camp at daybreak Tues morning for A53 Tps Itria.

All paraded & got leave for week-end.)
Entry.7:
On week-end leave from Sat. 10.30 a.m. till Monday 9.30 a.m.

Went to Burnley & Toorak, then Dandenong & then home.

Given diary by Joy
Entry.9:
Arrived back off leave.

News just come through that embarkation on Wednesday has been deferred till Friday.

Passedfinal medical exam for embarkation and had hair close cropped.

In afternoon our unit was taken for a swimming parade.

Interstate Artilelry, T.M.B. M. Grs, Cyclists, & A.S.C, units marched into camp at Seyr for embarkation this week.
Entry.10:
In camp. Our unit went out into the hills all the day and built improvised kitchens (field);shelters;and other requirements for camp sanitation.

Everybody disgusted still at the alteration of embarkation.

Came in at 5.30 pm and our O.C. announced that all orders regarding embarkation were cancelled.

(Boys nearly mad at this news.)
Entry.11:
In camp. Did underground "work" in the saps and mine tunnels, built by the miners and infantry. 1st work of this kind. It filled in time.

Furphies about embarkation still going strong.
Entry.12:
Still in camp.

Rumored
 that S.S. Ballarat has been sunk and only 600 troops saved.

Lt Horse (interstate) march in off "Itria (A53) to Seyr. Camp.

All day on the horses in the hills for Dvrs. Interesting but tiring work.

Light Horse Fd Amb bivouac being prepared by rest of unit.
Entry.13:
In camp.

On the horses all the morning in the hills, but in afternoon for the first time since I came into camp, I had to fall out as "
sick
".

Spent the afternoon resting in the tent.
Entry.14:
On leave. Week-end.

To Melbne. Stayed at Burnley 1st time that I never went home while on week-end leave since joining A.I.F.

The whole unit paraded against the Comp. Sgt-Major on the "Physical jerks" parade
Entry.15:
On leave. (Week-end).

Went to Dandenong for the day.

Back to Burnley at 9.30 p.m.
Entry.16:
Came back off week-end leave.

Everyone disappointed as no furphies available.

Did next to nothing in afternoon.

(Latest furphy. "Sailing Thursday".)
Entry.17:
In camp.

On B Section Mess orderly duties.

Had an easy day.

Rest of unit did transport work at the river
on
 with rafts.
Entry.18:
In camp.

At Lt. Horse Fd Amb. bivouac in the morning and in afternoon practised for sham battle with the 23/7th Lt Horse to take place tomorrow all day.

Latest furphy "Sailing
before
 about Monday 19th inst".

"Euripides" Artillery move out for, nobody knows where.

No lecture tonight.
Entry.19:
1st 
Sham 
fight that we (A.C.F.A) took part in.

The "white hats" were forced to retreat over the hills & across the "Trawool" bridge. Our No1 dressing station had to be disbanded in the retreat.

After dinner on the banks of Goulburn River we were marched in a round-a-bout way to the camp. Dist. 20 miles.

No lecture. "Furphies" still going strg.
Entry.20:
In camp.

Parade called by C.O. troops at Camp Hd Qrs regarding w-e leave for embarkation men.

Afternoon parade in full marching order. Inspection of universal & sea kit.

Paraded for week-end leave & were turned down.

Saturday 17 March 1917.

In camp till 11.45

2 car loads of C.B.F.A. went for a day to Negambie .

Left camp at 11.45 a.m. Sat morng.

First "blow-out" at 12.45 p.m. at Mangalore. Photo taken.

Second blow out at Tahbilk 1.45 pm.

Arrived Negambie 2.5 pm.

Had dinner at "Valley Hotel"

Left Negambie 3.10 p. for Weir.

Reached Lake Negambie 3.30 p.m.

Arrived Goulburn Weir 3.40 pm W.H 65' 9 

Took several snaps with V.P.R Auto. C.

Caretaker regulated flood gates to show us. 

Channel runs75 miles further from West Channel.

Left weir at 4.30 p.m arrived Negambie at 4.50 p.m. Went rowing on lake

Had tea 6.45 p.m at "Valley Hotel". 

Left Negambie 7.35 p.m. Puncture
Entry.21:
Blow-out 8.40. Arrived 9.40 at camp.

Everybody pleased with the outing
Entry.22:
In camp all day.

Did washing in the morning.

Beat L. J. L at Billiards 100 up.

Wrote letters in evening.

"Won billiard championship
of tent"
Entry.23:
Very little doing in camp.

Swimming parade in the Goulburn River.

C.B.F.A. recreation committee had a practise in the R.C. institute in evening.
Entry.24:
From the drill we have been given it seems as though we are to remain here some time yet & are to start our training again. Very monotonous work.

Signalling most of day.

1st case C.S.M. in Seyr camp this year.
Entry.25: Signalling & drill. Nothing startling. Usual routine
Entry.26:
Selected for class for topographical survey work & map planning and reading. 30 in the morng 8 in afternoon, Still in it.

Interesting work.

Printing some negatives of the Nagambie trip.

Fixed them in evening.
Entry.27:
Survey work & general drill.

Tents rearranged on acct. of sickness breaking out in the camp. 4 
men
to be in 1 tent.

Moved kit and settled again.

No lecture at night.

On acct of a clerical error I was granted leave from tonight until Monday night. Declined to go until morning train
Entry.28:
Up at 5.15. a.m. Caught 7. a.m. train from Seyr. Got to "
the dear old Lewis & Whitty" once more
 at 10 a.m. Spent morning in city & in afternoon had a good time. Caught 6.30 pm tram to Lyndhurst.

8.30 home once more. Bed 10.35p.m.
Entry.29:
At home on week-end leave. Went on the "Indian" in the morning to McLellands to take snaps.

Camera went crook– no resultsexpected 8 exposures.

Stayed at home in afternoon & evening. Bed 9 pm (New time.) (Clocks altered.)

Monday 26 March 1917.

On leave. Caught 10.45 a.m. train from Lyndhurst. Spent day very nicely at Dandenong & caught 4.48 pm. train to City, and 6.35 pm train to "
dear old
" Seymour camp. In camp 9.45. Bed 10.15 pm.

2 more

(Joy's birthday March 26th)
Entry.31:
In camp. Drill & signalling in morning and in afternoon, tents struck and everything well aired on acct. of 2 more cases of C.S M. today.

Lines picquet
s
 after this till 5.15 p.m.

Detailed for Hd Qrs fatigue tomorrow.
Entry.32:
Up at 6.15 a.m. At Hd Qrs at 6.45 pm. Fatigue till 7 p.m.

Furphy that all units except C. B. Fd. Amb. are embarking on "Nestor" & "Shropshire" before Easter.

(Another setback to us)
Entry.33:
More drill in morning & A.S.C. fatigue in afternoon. Lumping 80 lbs. cases of "bully beef". 50 lbs tins "dog" biscuits, bags of chaff, bran, & oats.

Announced on paradeby O.C. that we are sailing next week. Thurs probably.
Entry.34:
Route march into Seyr & out agn during morning.

A.S.C. fatigue in afternoon till 5.45. Late tea. Burnished spurs with marline spike. Visited L. J Laversha in ward at Clg Hosp.

Made bunk & then over to the lines.

Latest furphy. "Not sailing for 3 weeks."
Entry.35:
In camp. Duty again. This time Sanitary fatigue. Did washing in afternoon. Detailed to give A.M.C. a hand in the ward. Everyone going crook at this caper. Trust me I did very little work in the ward.

After 7 p.m. turned in early.

(Met Corp. Gray (cook) at Gar
r
isson in evening.)

L. J Laversha tent mate transferred to Base for treatment.
Entry.36:
Finished washing of Sat. afternoon

1 Set of bluies burnt in copper.

On no duty. Went in at 6.30 pm to Seyr with Pte E. R. Jenkins A.M.C. Saw G.S.Cn & his D'nong friends & went (on invitation) to see them off on the 7 p.m. train. Went with G.S.C. & C.R to C.R.'s home in Seyr & had supper. In bed at camp at 12.10 am.
Entry.37:
In camp & on no
duty
 special duty.

Signalling in morning.

Field stretcher work in afternoon till 3.15 p.m. Individual drill after smoke oh!

Lecture by Capt C J Oliver on Haemmorhage from 4.15 to 4.30 pm

(For first time in C.B.F.A. had½ hr. till 5 pm to ourselves.)

General Relief that we are not going this week.
Entry.38:
On no duty or fatigue.

Field day till 1.30 pm. in the hills by the river

In afternoon– pay, drill; & lecture by Major Morton

1st time– up to Orderly rooms for talking on parade. Absolutely no crime or charge agnst me.

Pte F. W. Bayley had a hamper sent to him from Nagambie so we had a good tea & supper in tent.

Some AMC. Reinfts cancelled. a ?
Entry.39:
Field day till 12.30 pm.

Afternoon easy.

Big riot of 1500 men in evening, on account of general camp conditions & Easter leave. Not much outcome of it. Men, especially interstate, riotous.

Wrote 2 letters & turned in feeling not too good.

P. J. Fogarty transferred for duty to No 11 A.G.H. (Downhearted.)

Allo AM.C Reinfts
unallotted
 now.
Entry.40:
Drill as usual. Field Work.

Easter leave to be from Fri evening until 9.30. a.m. Tues. morning.

Everybody indignant as we have to drill rmorrow– Good Friday.

Rained & our kit got wet.

Poor tents (bell)

12 men (C.B.F.A.) detailed for work at No 5 A.G.H. for 10 or 14 days.
Entry.41:
Never dreamtof ever seeing this Good Friday 1917 in Australia.

Drilled & a march of 14 mls in the hills. Easy afternoon.

Got ready for Er leave at 3.30 pm.

Marched into Seymour in rain.

Entrained 7 pm. Arrived City 9.30 pm.

Spent night at Burnley (74).
Entry.42:
On Easter Leave.

Met Joy in City. Out to D'nong in afternoon. 7.30 from D'nong to Lyndhurst. Homeonce more.

Father & I went to Mr. Stephens for evening. Had games of billiards. Played fair game.

Handed V. P. K. A. K. to "Kodaks" for repair on Sat morng.

Raining.
Entry.43:
H
Visitors at home. Ruby G. & Jack B.

Easter at home

To Dandenong in afternoon riding.

Went to Church in evening (Pres.)

Left D'nong 9 pm. & rode home in rain.
Entry.44:
Caught 10.45 am train to D'nong.

Spent day in D'nong & caught 8 pmtrain back to Melbourne.

Had a good day's enjoyment.

(Enjoyable Easter leave over)

Stayed at Burnley (74)

Bed at 10.45 pm
Entry.45:
Up at 5 a.m. 6.14 train from Burnley to City. 7 am troop train to Seyr. from Spencer St.

Arrived camp at 12 noon.

Signalling in afternoon.

Detailed for Camp Hd Qrs fatigue tomorrow. Wrote letters & back to lines. Bed at 9 pm.
Entry.46:
On Camp Head Quarters fatigue 6.30 Revlle.

Reported at 6.45 am. A solid day.

Reported off 7 pm. Furphies point to a move next week. Put in for special leave. New tent mates.
Entry.47:
In camp & on no fatigue.

Signalling drill, & in afternoon tent pitching.

Things rather quiet.

The longest march we have ever had is to be tomorrow.
Entry.48:
"
The day
". Reville 6.30. Roll call 6.45

Breakfast 7.30. Moved off 8.15 a.m, Trawool bridge at 9.30 a.m.

Turned on to Tallarook road & after another hours march were invited to a farmhouse for "morning tea" which we had in about½ hr. or over.

Tea very acceptable – new life in us. Pushed on & reached Tallarook at 12.30 pm.

¼ hrs spell.then on again.

Dinner by the road at 12.45

On again at 1.30. Reached Seymour at 3.30. SPell of 20 min.

Straight through to camp & reached there at 4.30.

On special leave from tonight till Monday morning. 8.15 train from Seyr. Expect
now
to move out on 23rd inst

Won competition for sketch of country etc.
Entry.49:
Stayed Federal Coffee Palace on Fri eveng

Up at 7.30 & after a time out to Burnley.

In city on Sat morning.

Out to Toorak in afternoon.

Met Joy at 5.50 in city & after tea went to "Canary Cottage" at "Her Majesty's theatre". (Joy lost her purse.)

Bed at 12.30 am. at Burnley

Most enjoyable evening.
Entry.50:
Up at 8.30 a.m. Caught 11.5 train from Flinders St to Dandenong.

Spent till 4.15 pm at "Elstre".

4.25 train to Lyndhurst.

6.10 pm train from Lyndhurst.

Till 8 train spent evening D'nong

Back to Melbourne by 8 train.

Arrived Burnley 9.45 pm.

An enjoyable week-end.
Entry.51:
Up at 5 p.m. Caught troop train at 7 pm from Spencer St.

Arrived in camp at 11.45 a.m.

Was marched over to races in afternoon and then back to camp at 6.15 pm.

Tea in the dark at 6.30 p.m.

 Wandered round doing nothing at the racecourse.

Wrote a letter
s
 after tea & turned in at 9.15.

Heard Pat Lynch has been wounded.
Entry.52:
On no fatigue duty. Signalling during morning after we came back from C. QM's store.

Pay and tent pitching in afternoon.

a/g State Commondant Bgdier Gen Willmvisited camp. "A red tape visit".

Bed at 8.30.

No furphies.
Entry.53:
Tent pitching during morning.

1st fog of the season this morning

Swim in Goulburn in afternoon, arrange tents & lecture.

Water very cold. Nobody stayed in.

Reported to Camp Hd. Qrs for duty for tomorrow.

Wrote 4 letters.
Entry.54:
On Staff Sgt's Major's Mess fatigue

Reported on 6.45 am. A solid day's work but treated the work as a joke. Reported off 7.15 p.m.

Never wrote any letters tonight

Bed early 8.45 a.m.



Friday 20 April 1917.

The march. Early breakfast.

Left camp 8.25. Trawool bridge 9.30

1st Hill reached summit &was 4th on the highest peak at 10.15 

Some climb too. 

Trawool weir at 11.15 

Trawool falls 11.25.

Dinner at T'wool Hotel at 2.15 

Rested
Entry.55:
hr on the road. Arrived camp 4.30. Shower &tea. Early to bed.

We carried water bottle &haversack each. The scenery was 
beautifu
l
in the gully below the Trawool falls. Best part near Seymour for scenery. 

Volunteered for week-end duty.
Entry.56:
In camp and on fatigue duty. On ASC. fatigue lumping stores & loading & unloading wagons during morning and inafternoon on A M.C. QM's fatigue. 

Rather easy in afternoonand was able toget washing done. 

Camp seems deserted. All on extended leave. 2.400 troops marched out on leave today. 

Did some w
a
shing
Entry.57:
In camp & on fatigue duty. On A.M.C. QM's fatigue.

A little spare time in afternoon.

Went down to service at the lines in evening.

Wrote 2 letters in afternoon & did some mending & sewing. Soon got tired & assisted the Mess orderlies.

More washing done
Entry.58:
On duty A.M.C Q M's fatigue

Not extra much doing

Washing completed at last.

Met F. Girdler & C. Lockie 
back off final leave in A.M.C
Entry.59:
On ASC. fatigue. An easy day as I assisted as driver on one of the G.S. wagons

Boys back off leave.

Met Ern Palmer
returned AM.C. &has just had final to go back again
Entry.60:
Signalling & tent pitching in morning & same in afternoon.

Some practised for Friday's sports (Military)

Otherwise things quiet.

Nothing doing about sailing.
Entry.61:
Practise for events at the Military Sports in Seyrtomorrow.

In the march past practise for the Ceremonial Parade the A.C.B.F.A came out on top & were complimented by LA Col Semmens.

Things contented.
Entry.62:
"The" day - a big one for Seyr & district. 

The Ceremonial Parade in the reserve near Seyr at 10.15 am. was a "grand sight" & a "success" 

Bivouac carried out for lunch after the review
ordermarch.


4000 troops took part. Colonel Semmens took
part
salute. 

Aust. Camel,
Bgde
Fd.Amb. headed the march through Seymour at 1pm. 

Sports program carried out in Kings Park in afternoon. A.C.
B
.F.Awon relay race &stretcher competition.. 

Caught the 5 minto 5 pmtrainfrom Seyr. to Melbne on leave. 

Stayed at Toorak
& then intocity in M morn
Entry.63:
Up at 8.30 am. & went into city. 
F.C M never turned u
p.

WithFrank Pratt
introduced me to
andLt Bizley on the block. Had dinner at Y.M.C.A.Soldiers Club at 12.45 p.m. 

To Dandenong on 4.35 p.m. train from City. 

Tea in Dandenong (Thomas St) & caught 7.30 train to Lyndhurst. 

Bed at 12 midnight.
Entry.64:
At home on leave,F. Prattat home alsoat Lyndhurst. 

Went for a ride on Jack's Indian in the morning. 

Spent evening at Stephen's. 

Home at 11.30 pm.
Entry.65:
On leave. 

Caught 10.45 am train and went as far as Dandenong. 

In afternoon went along Melbne road for walk for a mile or so. Came back at 5 pm. 

An enjoyable walk tooand a fine day. 

7.46pmtrain to City. 

Stayed at Federal Palace Hotel 

Crook during night.
Entry.66:
Up at 5 a.m. & caught 6.15 pm. train from Spencer St. Got to camp at 9.30 a.m. & stayed in tent till 12 noon. 

On a big march tomorrow. 

Nothing much doing. 

Rumors are that we sail on 10thinst.
Entry.67:
Reveille 6.30. No physical jerks. 

In full marching order left camp at 8.26 a.m. Spell 5 mins. Trawool Bdge at 9.25. Trawool Hotel 10. a.m. Left 10.15 a.m. Spell 5 mins. Kerrisdale 11.24 (station) 1.8 p.m. Homewood. Dinner here. 

Now gone 19 miles. One 11 mile non stop walk.
Nothing to eat since breakfast
. 

2.26 pm. onward to Yea. (Breaking up of the boys.) 4 pm arrived in Yea.Decent reception. Supper & bed 10.30

Too tired to sleep. Capt Heath & 20 others (myself included) slept in Shire Hall. (Got cup of tea at Homewood at a farmhouse on the way up.)
Entry.68:
Reveille at 6.10 a.m. Breakfast at
8 p
8 a.m. Left Yea 8.30 a.m.

Homewood 10.20
p
a.m.

Setting for final plunge to "CAMP".

Dinner at Kerrisdale & some more dropped out. Horses in G.S transport wagon knocking up.

Now gone 12 miles. Next stop atTrawool Hotel at 3 pm. Left Trawool Hotel at 3.15 pm. (After lunch we left Kerrisdale at 1.37 p.m.)

Arrived in camp at 5.15 p.m.

After
tea
ashower then tea & turned in at 8.30 p.m.
Entry.69:
Every
one
bodytired of general breakups. 

Reveille 7 p.m.for our unit only. 

1stparade at 9 p.m. 

Made out "Will" forms, & did nothing in general. 

Official word that we are to sail next week, & everyone in A.C.
B
.F. Amb. granted leave for week-end. 

Bed 10 pm. after getting some washing done.
Entry.70:
In camp in the morning as not having a vote was on "fatigue" cleaning up the lines.

2ndtroop train to Melbourne from Seymour at 1.45 pm.

A very dirty & dusty march from camp to station.

1/3 of the boys had to ride in cars as result of march on Wed. & Thursday.

Arrived City. 4.10 pm. Caught 4.35 pm. train from Flinders St.

Had tea in D'nong. & caught train later (7.30) to Lyndhurst.

Home at 8.15 pm. Spent evening at home & bed at 11.30 pm.

Present from "Gannons" Deniliquin.
Entry.71:
On leave. Home during day.

Writing walletgiven me by Mother in evening before leaving,Wallace's from Bayswater over for dinner & left at 6.
15
pm.

Caught 6.10 train from Lyndhurst. Stayed 1½ hours in Dandenong & then got 8 pm train to Melbourne.

Wrote note & turned in 11 pm. at Fed. Coffee Palace.
Entry.72:
Up at 6a.m. Caught 7 pm troop train to Seymour. At Camp at 11.30 a.m.

Very little doing but we were drilled in cold wind & misty rain.

Expect to go on Thursday

Advance guard forLt. Horse on A42 leave camp at 6.15 a.m.

A.M.C. (re-allotted men) about 30 arrive from No 5 & No 11. A.G.H. at 9.30 p.m.
Entry.73:
Very little drill doing but things busy about embarkation.

Returned stores & struck some tents during morning.

Afternoon ―drill ―packed kit bag (universal) and placed in "store" for A.S.C. At 8 pm. placed on G. S. Wagon for removal tomorrow morning at 4 a.m.

Advance guard for A.C.
B
.F
d
.A.
mb
.detailed.

Wrote 10 notestonight & posted same.

A cold as result of Monday. 1st cold since last October.

A.M.C. (2 lots) leave for various transports.
Entry.74:
Drill in morning, and in afternoon preparing for tomorrow.

"Sweet" has deserted & "Summers" offers₤30 to get on the strength of A.C.B.F.A. Maitland took him up.

(Addressed by Lt. Col. Semmens and asked to "fight like the devil!!" What did he think we were??)

"Marching" & "marching out" order parade.

Instructions for tomorrow issued.

Eve of embarkation. Boys happy. A party serenading the lines. Kits (universal) now on boat. Final touch up of kit (sea) & turned in.

(Wrote 2 "farewell" letters.)
Entry.75:
Reveille 2.30 am. Breakfast 3 am.

Sea kits on baggage wagon 3.15 am. 

"Fall in" on parade ground in full marching order 3.45 a.m. Left camp 4.15 am. Entrained at Seymour Station 5.25 am. Arrived at Port Melbourne 8 p.m. Disentrained & marched to boat's side. Marched on board 11.30 a.m.
Embarked
Sailed 12.15 pm.

(Visitors not allowed on pier at all.)

Anchored just inside heads 4.30 pm. Tea at 4.35 pm. Clan McGill
ll
iveray anchored close by at 4.45 pm.

Slung hammocks at 7 p.m. for 1st time. Went on deck again & turned in.

Transport (A42) "Boorara".
Entry.76:
Reveille 6 a.m. Still at anchor inside "the heads". A small gunboat anchored close by.

At 4.45 pm the "Shropshire" anchored by & at 5 pm. the "Ascanius" did same.

There are now 4 transports & 1 gun boat in the bay ready to move out. During day usual routine of mess orderly on board a troopship. Am on that job till next Thursday.

Boxes of amusements opened in evening and there is some discord on the musical instruments. Hammocks slung at 6 p.m. Bed at 8.30 p.m.

Not properly in the ways of the ship's routine.

Expect to move on tomorrow.

Met Adams in the Cl. Corps.
Entry.77:
2 more transports came up with troops during day and anchored close by. A rough cold day.

Mess orderly duty as usual today Getting into the way of things now. Fellows taking more to the life of the ship. 
No one seasick yet.
 At5.15 pm. A destoyer 
"a real beauty too"
 The "Warrego". came in the bay, & cut the pace out & lying low in the water. Signalling going on everywhere between boats. 5.20 pm 
6.0 pm.
 weighed anchor & 6.0 pm all the transports started to move slowly towards "heads". All going on deck to watch us going through the heads shortly. 6 35 pm through the heads. Boat rolling now in open sea. A beautiful sight with searchlights playing between the heads.
Entry.78:
My 20th birthday. Woke up seasick at 6 a.m. A cold wind blowing.

Hail & rain storms at intervals.

Everything bleak & desolate. Nothing in sight but water everywhere.

Boat shipping seas. Very rough weather but boat is riding well. Hope I never spend another birthday like this one. Could not stand down below so had to stay above deck.

Everybody crook with one or two exceptions. Waves bigger than I've ever seen before.

Turned in early as I felt very crook.

We have after leaving "the heads" come well down south off Tas. west coast.

Geo. C. looked after me. He was not sea-sick.
Entry.79:
Up at 6.30 am. Feeling crook, but soon seemed to pick up again.

Sea at present not quite so rough.
Nothing in sight but water.
All the boats in sight number 10 transports, 2 cargo boats & 2 destroyers. "Warrego" & "Encounter"

We have now caught up the boats from Sydney. Seas heavy –boat shipping a few.

"Shropshire" in front of us rolling terribly. Able now to stand it down below. Took 2 snaps of "Shropshire" rolling. Went below & wrote 6 letters.

Glad to turn in at 6 p.m. as the seamen told us that towards morning we would be entering 'the bight. Have now turned West towards direction of the Bight.

Tuesday
Entry.80:
A little more recovered from the sea sickness & feeling hungry. Went up on deck at 6.30am

Rather a rough day today.

Boat drill during morning.

Our boat right close to the "Encounter" & near the lead.

In the bight now. Back at Mess Orderly duties again with G.S.S.C. (who has acted
a dinkum cobber
to me while crook with seasickness.)

Towards afternoon sea rougher

Ran into a storm later & at night it is bitterly cold up on deck. Band playing down on No 4 deck cheering things up.

Everybody brighter today. Feeling better. Wrote 6 cards afternoon.

(Lost one of E M V's mittens)

Are now well down in Sthn Ocean
Entry.81:
Still at sea and still no sight of land. Spent a better day & feeling almost right again.

Everyone still a little more brighter. Wrote 1 letter in afternoon and with ship rolling heavily upsetting plates. knives forks from shelves.

Wind not so strong & sea not
quite
so rough.

We are now over
500 miles from
land
usual route
down in the "Roaring Forties" Very rough weather indeed. Are well out of sight of any shipping of any description along Sth coast of Australia

('Warrego" destroyer left us yesterday Tues 15thinst.)

Only one escort with us now.
Entry.82:
Still at sea and we are of the opinion that we are just now in "bight"judging by the very rough weather we have run into

The roughest day yet of the voyage,since leaving Melbourne.

Ast.Cl.
Bgde
Fd Amb. does guard. & police duties on board.

Medical inspection in afternoon

A very rough night. Sat on upper deck till 9 p.m. & then down below.

Have veered
slightly
in a Northerly direction but are stll about 500 miles from land.
Entry.83:
No sight of land yet. Right up close to "Encounter" (cruiser) this morning. Rough at first but not quite so later.

I finish up my mess orderly duties with G.S.S.Crmntoday, for a month or so.

Expect to. sight land tomorrowevening.

Still in a northerlyly direction as on Thursday 17thinst

Saw with 2 of the boys a
"transparent"
"flying fish". An uncommon sight so far south in a cold climate.
Entry.84:
No sight of land yet this morning. Everyone looking out for it all the same all day. No Result

On no duty today and feel benefit of being above deck in fresher air.

A good day at sea all the day, today. Feeling, good oh! now.

At 12.15 p.m. we followed the Cruiser "Encounter" in a decided Nth Wstly direction.

Believe we are fairly close to land compared to before.

Close to "Encounter" all day.

Sing-song up on deck in evening

G.S.S.Crmn& I thinking where we would be at this time if on week-end leave in Vic.

10 days. now since leaving Pt. Melb. pier.
Entry.85:
Still no sight of land.

Everyone writing letters today as mail closes. tomorrow morning.

Sat up on the top deck reading during morning after church parade.

At 12 noon. (exactly) the
destr
cruisers 2 now turned completely North from West & continued so in that direction. We have now rounded the coast at the Sth Wstnextremity of Australia. A good sea & a smooth trip today.

At 10.30 p.m. last night another Cruiser picked us up "Doris" an imperial cruiser. A nice appearancetooand bringing up the rear of our "fleet".

Expect to be in Freemantle tomorr-ow morningearlynow.

6 pmtravelling very slow in calm sea4 Knots an hr
Entry.86:
Land sighted at 9 a.m. Heavy mist. Sea calmer. Anchored 10.30 a.m. just out of Fremantle. Shore quite close. Everyone pleased at seeing houses from distance.

Motor launch "Dauntless" came along side our boat A 42. "Boorara" and discharged her cargo of fruit (Y.M.C.A. Comforts Fund gift)

Fruit issued in afternoon. Sea now calm as mill-pond & sun shining on Fre
e
mantle—a Pretty sight. The 2 escorts "Encounter" & "Doris" nowhere to be seen.

4 transports weigh anchor & steam slowly to Fremantle up "Swan River"

Cleaned up all equipment. A Japanese Cruiser (1 mast
ed
) entered "the Rose" & anchored. A great night on upper deck.

Transports actually with us now are:–
"Shropshire", "Boorara (A42)', "Clan McGuily", 'Port. Sydy." A15, "Ascanius", "Tofua" (NZ25), Marathon", "Canadian", "Benalla" "Armadale", "Ulysses".
Entry.87:
Weighed anchor 8.30 a.m. Towed byatug to wharf & made fast at 9.30 am. People threw fruit to us all the time. 50 W.A (.M.M.G.S) embarked at 10 a.m. on our boat. 30 C. Corps jumped to wharf & took leave.

A parade at 1.45 pm in uniform with belts on, & at 2 pm. disembarked for a march
at 2pm.
to Nth Fremantle. Back at boat at 4.15 pm. & boat drew away at 5.15 pm. Anchored at 5.30 pm. in "the Rose". Japanese Cruiser sigld& we weighed anchor at 6.15 pm & followed her (cruiser) into the night, where??

Fremantle people gave us
an exceptionally good reception
in every way. Fruit in galore & crowds gave us an enthusiastic welcome. "Doris" & "Encounter" were in at wharf all day & Doris left wharf at 3 pm.

I had the best day since leaving Melbourne.

One patient transferred to hosp. on land. at 9.30 a.m.

Volunteers called for stokehold as 5 of crew deserted at Frtle .
Entry.88:
Woke up & went
up
on deck at 5 a.m. to find that we are now well out at sea again & when sun rose at¼ to 7 a.m. I found we were travelling in a Nth. –Nth West course. A calm sea– hardly a ripple & boat travelling well 10½ knots an hr (Log).

Physical training for 1½ hrs. this morng.

The transports etc. with us now are "Port Sydney" & our escort– a Japanese Cruiser– (1 masted.) Games, lecture & a hair cut (close crop) in afternoon.

The weather today was warm & shows signs of being warmer still in a day or so.

Examined ships "log" at 4.30 p.m.
Entry.89:
Now well out into the open sea and nearing the "danger zone". A very calm sea today hardly a ripple on the water & a fresh breeze blowing.(11 Knots an hr today.) Awnings spread today. Got into shorts and put away woollen clothing. The opening concert on board ship this afternoon (Empire Day)

False "fire alarm" at 2.15 p.m.

Absolutely
 no light of any description after dusk from now on

Cruiser on alert now. Tonight sea is "as smooth as glass".

Compulsory washing parade in morng.

Cake cigarettes, lollies & apples issued by Y.M.C.A to all on board.

A scare l
ast
 this morning at 3 a.m. Cruiser prepared for action when we came acrosss a sailing boat that altered her course quickly & put on speed.
Entry.90:
Furtherstillinto the "danger zone"
still
.

A slight swell this morning. Marching order parade at 10 a.m. (All kit correct.). Physical training from 2 pm. till 4 pm. Games on deck later till 5 p.m. Did some sewing from 6 to 8 p.m.

Tonight swell about the same although the surface of the water is unbroken by any ripple. Perhaps & indication of stormy weather coming?

1stcase of C.S M. on board.
Entry.91:
A little warmer still today & sea not quite so
rough
smooth.

Swell as usual and surface a little disturbed.

Physical jerks for 1½ hrs. 10 to 11.30 a.m.

Travelling 10½ knots an hr. today.

Flying fish (1 shoal) seen this afternoon at the bows of boat.

this morning "Port Sydney" practised with her maxim gun across the water. In afternoon from the stern from boat(A42)the C.Otroops on board & another officer practise with revolvers.

Cool onupperdeck but on troop deck very close tonight.
Entry.92:
Crook during early morning. It rained at 5 p.m. All sleeping above came below. Speed at 7 a.m. 11 knots an hr. Good sea all day. Travelled well. Church parade at 10 a.m. up on boat deck. Wrote letters down on troop deck. Entered for sports events for Tuesday. 2 more shoals of "flying fish seen by those on upper deck in afternoon. Sing-song after dark & turned in at 8 pm.

Another case of "mumps" today.

Today we passed near Cocos Is. where Emden "was" sunk by Sydney
H.M.S.
Entry.93:
The hottest day so far.

Physical jerks in morning.

Saw hundreds of flying fish this morning. 9 to 15 ins. long & wings varying according to size of fish. Wings are really large fins & are transparent. Frightened by boat they(fish)rise 3 or 4 feet above water and fly away from boat for a distance of from 20 to75 or100 yds. when they are no sooner in one wave & out into the crest of the next.

"Mock trial" (for bigamy) on the upper deck from 3 pm to 5 pm.

Wrote 1 letter this afternoon & missedthetrial.

Sleeping on deck tonight in deck space allotted to A.C.
B
.F.A.
Entry.94:
Flying fish seen today by the hundred. Another very hot dayand sea a little rougher today.

1stsports meeting this afternoon.

Physical jerks during morning– a practice for the competition in the sports. One of the 15. Japanese Cruiser moving very quickly into various positions yesterday & today.

Sports caused amusementamong the boys.

Wrote 2 letters.

Detailed for guard duty tomorrow to mount at 9 am.

Sleeping on deck again tonight.

G.S.S.Cmn& Iwent down below into stokehold & engine room, & right along to end of propeller shaft.

Speed nowFullas indicated on dial above log book below.
Entry.95:
Fell in with guard at 8.45 a.m.

Inspected on boat deck above and then marched to guard room in the forecastle.

Mounted duty on No 9 post port aft. at 1 till 2 pm.; 2 to 3 pm (No 5 deck) No 8 post.relieved at 3 pm. marched back to guard room & dismissed until 7 p.m. when I go on till 9 pm.

Tea at 5 pm. Mounted guard at No 9 post
port aft
at 7 pm till 9 pm.

Slept on deck for 1
½
hr
s
or so & then a monsoonal wind sprung up in 5 mins & was compelled to go below & sleep in guard room

Air stifling here & could not sleep
Entry.96:
Up at 5 a.m. Mounted guard on No 7 post from 7 am till 9 a.m. (No 6 & 7 decks aft)

Air very bad on No 3 troop deck.

Dismissed at 9.15 am. Did washing

Marching order parade at 1.30 pm I was minus 1 cap & 1 boot, found cap later but not other boot.

Awning taken down altogether as a monsoonal disturbance is expected tonight. Hatchways closed over.

G.S.S.Crmn & I went down to Engine Room, propeller shaft tube, & stokehold at 6 pm.

Sleeping on deck & chancing rough weather.

3 wks now since leaving Port Melbne.
Entry.97:
"
Crossed the line
" at 10 a.m.

Have developed another cold, & unluckily I am mess orderly again.
with
G.S.S.Cmrn on with me.

Rough weather– a big swell on.

Air still foul in No 3 deck.

Dinner 11.30 am (early) and preparations for "crossing the line" initiation at 2.30 pm

Great sport & everyone being drenched to the skin. No distinctions drawn between officers & men. Officers faring worst.

I had to go through the performance and have now "crossed the line"

Travelling 8 knots (slow) tonight 7.30 pm.

Very heavy seas. Boat shipping them very badly. WIth heavy head feeling crook, turned in early.
Entry.98:
"
Still at sea
"& air very foul in No 3 & No 4 deck. Paraded with bad cold & was given "no duty". (1sttime since entering camp that I've had to parade sick). Japanese Cruiser signalling 
"short of coal"

We are now 1 day behind time & at 6 pm have 155 tons of coal left in bunkers to get to Colombo– now 250 miles away.

Stayed above deck & read & yarned. Went aft at 6 pm & watched "log".

Air slightly improved & cold feeling a shade better.

Speed 8 to 10 knots per hr.
Entry.99:
Air in No 3 deck a little better in morning and worse toward eveng.

Detailed in charge of Isolation Guard and
given
made Corporal of the Guard
for a week or so
. Took charge at 9 am.

A rather crook day as regards the weather. Monsoonal rains or really storms every hr or so. Sky is clear then in 5 to 10 mins it is blowing a howling wind & the rain coming down in deluges.

Expect to get into Colombo tomorrow morning. Several more of the soldiers "tommies" are now working in the stokehold. 3 boats now keeping close together. Speed varying from½,¾ to full speed. Birds (stormy petrel) seen in hundreds at 6 p.m.
Entry.100:
Land sighted at 8 a.m. and then again at 10 a.m. Still in charge of guard on isolation. Fastened to buoys inside breakwater at Colombo at 12 noon. Coolies started to coal our transport at 2 pm. Some came alongside in small "bum" boats and dived for money. Some of the boys changed money with the "niggers" while the "Harbour Police" were not watching

On our right is the main fortress of Colombo. Trading boats coming into the breakwater harbour all day.

Port Sydney anchored close by. Some of the boys off our boat swam over & on return were "clinked". Shoals of porpoises seen. 2 extra other cruisers escorted us the last 50 miles to Colombo & all 3 are now in harbor.
Entry.101:
Lying in harbor. Coaling operations finished on "Port Sydney" (A15) at 10 a.m. and on our boat "Boorara" (A42) at 1 p.m. At 2 p.m. we weighed anchor and after the ropes were unfastened from buoys we moved out of the harbor (breakwater.) and now at 4 pm. we are now out at sea once more. During the morning I changed some of our money for the Ceylon coinage. (Sinagelese)

A whale has just been seen by some of the boys at 4 pm.

Officers on the boat especially the O.C. troops, on board showed themselves to be no men and treated us like dirt
 while anchored in harbor.

Port Sydney moved out 2 hrs before us and with no escort same as us. On leaving there were 5 cruisers at Colombo.

Took snaps with V.P.K.(A) camera.
Entry.102:
At sea and now at 2 pm we are 1 days sail from Colombo. Fresh foodstuffs at Canteen are much dearer now.

At 1.30 pm a boat sighted on horizon.

Gazetted Corporal as from 3/6/17 in Ships Orders for voyage only. Put up 2 stripes this morning.

Fire started in the ships coal bunkers at 2.15 pm, and continued so until night and at 9.30 a ship on horzon was ordered to stand by in case of emergency
and
as the ships officers could not locate fire at all. Everything was in readiness and ships officers stood by all night. A little excitement. ("Our first fire at sea".)
Entry.103:
Fire not yet located but smoke
d
has ceased to issue from air vents. Watch & precautions still being taken. One boat in sight at 7 a.m. but now as far as we know we are "unescorted and alone in open ocean".

Weather moderate. Did washing during morning & more in afternoon. Wrote home in aftern.

C/pl in charge of Isolation & no fault found in any way at the inspection.
Entry.104:
Weather moderate & a decent day at sea in a few ways. Duties on Isolation do not allow of parade etc. with rest of the unit.

Still unescorted. Attended N.C.O's lecture parade at 4 pm on boat deck. Had a look at negatives of one of the Ship's engineers,– negs of snaps taken on last trip to Engd & air raid on Engsh. coast.
Entry.105:
Busy with moving Isolation during morning and in afternoon the 2nd concert of the trip was held at 3 pm. Not much of a success.

Wrote 2 or 3 letters after 2.30 pm.

Rather a very warm day today.

Infectious cases of mumps, & measles are very prevalent on boat now.
Entry.106:
On Isolation and have now charge of No 1 Troop Deck & 14 C.B.F.A. boys.

Sea rather rough & tonight rough weather & rain is expected. Duties kept me from church parade.

Infectious cases still increasing

Wrote 1 letter this afternoon. Mail closes 6 p.m. Friday next.
Entry.107:
Still on duty and fairly solid too

Sea rough & resembling the bight. Transport shipping seas a good deal. Fire in bunker or hold started again. Foul air starting again also.

Wrote letters in spare time in morng & afternoon.

I am now looking after 42 out patients,
&
mumps & measles, 3 scabies & 6 V.D's. patients.
Entry.108:
Sea rougher than ever and the roughest we have had yet during the voyage. Seas coming
in
over port
the
 side as much as 5 feet over the
outside
above railing. Rafts torn away from their lashings & hurled into center of deck. One man washed on to a raft & had clavicle, & 2 ribs broken & a cut head also.

Case of enteric fever on board.

Sighted a liner this morning on port side on horizon. Sea calming down a little in afternoon. We have now passed Cape Gardafui & things should be a little calmer. Finished correspondence for this mail this afternoon. 2 boxing contests coming off. Extra large flying fish seen today.
Entry.109:
Sea a lot calmer this morning and we will soon be in the Gulf of Aden.

Two boats– 1 tramp & 1 liner passed us going in direction of Colombo at 6.30 a.m. 2 sharks 12 feet long following boat with a dozen or so smaller ones. Several whales seen some distance away at 9 a.m. One came up on surface & was plainly seen. All were spouting. Flying fish were being chased by ("Beeneta")
(Dolfins)
fish . These (Beeneta)
(Dolfins)
are as long as 5 feet and of a bluish green color. They can swim very fast.

At 6.30 pm a large shoal of porpoises was seen close to boat.
In early hours of tomorrow morning we pass Aden.
2 boxing contests this afternoon. Heat very great & atmosphere moist & very oppressive.
Entry.110:
A very hot morning and a good breeze. Slept on deck
last night
but on account of wind had to come below at 3 a.m. while crew removed awning. Dolphins seen again today.

Tonight we pass Perrim & Appaur and enter the Red Sea. Slept below.

Friday 15 June 1917.

Went up on deck at
5 p
5 a.m. and on starboard side a lighthouse showing a powerful light was to be
bee
seen.

Guard on upper deck reported having seen during night 1 liner lit up and 2 gun boats cruising round Perrim. 4 lighthouses also seen. At 9 a.m. a tramp steamer crossed our bows and we then passed her on her port side.

Land sighted quite close. We could plainly see the "12 apostles". on
starboard side. portside.
Looked at them through field glasses.
Entry.111:
projections now on port side Passed very close. 2 boats on starboard side (horizon) seen at 6 pm.

Land on same side seen at 7 pm &1 lighthouse. (7 sisters.)

Full dress parade at 2.30 pm today.

Another lighthouse seen at 9 p.m.

Peculiar red fish seen
today
also.
Entry.112:
Still in Red Sea and a very hot day but breeze is fairly strong making all the difference.

A number of boats seen todayMost of them going in direction of Aden.

No land yet today at 3.30 pm. Several shoals of "dolfins" seen right against boat. Mail steamer passed at 3 p.m.

Sickness on boat decreasing

Wireless news of last air raid on London published today. 397 killed & 439 injured. (mostly women & children.).
Entry.113:
Slept up on deck and got up at 5 a.m. and went for usual shower before 6 a.m. (reveille.) Went to church parade at 10 am, "Axie" & A.S.T. spoke & Capt Chap Lydgate gave a short but impressive address. It was very good.

Sports in afternoon. In the "O'Grady" drill
went
competion the C.B.F.A. team won. JRL. & myself being only ones left . Prize for team£3/15/-

Land on Port side sighted at 6 pm. in the shape of rugged mountains.

Several boats seen today.
Entry.114:
Still in the Red Sea. A hot day but breeze makes the day a little pleasant. No boats seen today.

Universal kit bags brought up from "hold" & during afternoon we were given access to them.

Special parade at 1.45 pm. on account of a letter written by E.P.O'R. of A.C.B.F.A. I was exempt
ed
from parade and so arranged my kit etc prior to disembarkation which we expect will be Wed. morning. Reveille will be at 
5 a.m.
 tomorrow morning.

Passed the "Deathless" lighthouse at 5 p.m.
Entry.115:
Reveille at 5 a.m. Went up on deck and land is now to be seen on either side. We are now in the Straits of Sinai. Land rugged and of a limestone sandy formation no vegetation.Speed slow and boats to be seen the whole day. Through these Sts we passed Sinai and were then in Gulf of Suez.Arrived in Suez harbor at 6.15 pm. Launches came alongside with naval & military officers.

2 aeroplanes were circling over a number of very large oil
drums
tanks on coast & apparently guarding them.Dropped anchor at 7. pm.

In harbor is a sunken boat with bridge only showing. A pretty sunset noted.

Disembarkation tomorrow morning.

(Another case of C.S.M. at 11 pm. ?)
Entry.116:
Reveille 4.am. "Port Sydney" beside us in the harbor. Breakfast 5 a.m. In full marching order water bottle filled, a few biscuits in haversack and with sea & universal kit bags we paraded on upper deck at 6.45 a.m. C.B.F.A.disembarked at 9 a.m. & marched straight into open trucks. Took off gear & kits and arranged ourselves in trucks. Placed in 
ourselves
charge of truck & was in with 20 odd others.

Train moved off from wharf at 9.45 amArrived MoascarCamp (n), Ismalia at 12.45 p.m. & disentrained immediately. Carrying our sea kits & wearing full equipment we marched across the desert to the Isolation camp site 1½ miles from main camp. Tea issued to some.C.B.F.A. got none so had to use our biscuits and water. Threw off equipment & had to turn to and pitch tents– 280 tents pitched by "Boorara" troops. "Port Sydney" troops arrived at 4.30 pm. (after we had pitched their tents.)

Thursday 21 June 1917.

Reveille 4 a.m. Parade in fatigue dress with waist belts at 4.45 a.m. Physical jerks & mounted drill on foot on desert till 7.30 a.m.

Breakfast 8 p.m. Fall in at 9.30. Parade till 10.30 am & then reallotted to tents at 11 p.m. 

Aeroplanes (biplanes) flying above us all the time we are on parade. As many as 8 "planes" up at a time. Parade at 3 pm till 4.40 pm. Tea at 5 p.m. of bread jam & tea.

Dinner was stew & tea. 6 weeks today since we embarked from Pt. Melbourne on May 10th.

Arab
Egyptian women came to camp but guard prevented them from entering.

Wed. 20th 1917.Allotted to our tents at 6.30 pm

Issued with 1 blanket. Tea at 8 p.m. of bully beef & biscuits. At 9.30 p.m. turned in on the sand & dead tired. We passed through Suez today. There is a large naval store of petrol & benzine here. Submarine & aeroplane base also.
Entry.117: Same routine as yesterday morning. Heard news of latest push at Gaza. 14000 casualties altogether & over 4000 killed. Remains of 3 aeroplanes (accidents) brought down, were seen on the trucks on Wednesday. Train load of camels went through to Cairo. Camel corps in desert have been cut up lately at
Entry.118:
Gaza stunt.

An issue of bread yesterday & today. A mail expected up today. The main Moascar camp is practically all "Tommies" at present who came from Salonika 5 days ago & are soon to go on to the firing line at Gaza. 1 batch left yesterday. Returned men that have been at Gallipoli and Gaza say that Gaza is worse than the Gallipoli problems.

Canteen opens, both
wet
&
dry
.

"Tommies" from Salonika arrive at main 
Moskar
 Moascar camp (n), Ismalia.
Entry.119:
Usual routine & extra work this morning with extra work again during afternoon out on the desert in the scorching sun.2 more aeronauts killed (accidents to aeroplanes.) Aeroplanes still continue to fly above us all the day & some practice at shooting from them.More wounded
arrive
pass through here from Gaza. (Minor cases.)

A hospital train goes to Suez, and a train load of Camels and another of supplies seen passing our camp.Cases of mumps & measles break out.

We are beginning to see that our soldiering in Vic. 
is
was play to what we get here.

I ran of tobacco & cigarettes.

Working late till 6.30 pm.
Entry.120:
Reveille 6 a.m. but the "planes" who were flying as early as 3.30 a.m. kept us awake.Fatigue work nearly all day, preparing 
for
 the area where our complete unit is to be in training. Fillingsandbags and erecting tents. Were kept away from church parade. Had to stand by as special fatigue but was not required.Niggers who encroached on our parade grounds were chased by the police on horseback.Wrote one letter 1st since arriving in Egypt
Entry.121:
4 a.m. reveille. Drill till 7.30 a.m.

Practice for coming N.C.O's exam.

At 10.30 a.m. full dress parade & were officially handed over to D.G.M.S. by Lt Colonel Croll. DIsmissed & went to our tents at 11.30 a.m.

Another batch of troops left for firing line last night at 12 mnght.

Hospitaltrain passed through to Suez. Train of wagons arrives at main camp. Moved kits & tents during afternoon to new sight .

 In the morning for a time was on fatigue in charge of party.
Entry.122:
The parades this morning were under Lt Col. Croll. our O.C. (orig 2nd L.H.F.A.) & he complimented us on our marching etc. He said it was best of any Fd Amb. that had come to Egypt. Allotted to different 
divizions
 sectionsfor active service in the field. I was allotted as Stretcher Bearer. George Cameron & I are now separated in this respect.

Issued with plate & pannikin & khaki shorts during afternoon. Up to this date since disembarkation we were compelled to use our mess tin for all meals.

Mess orderly for B mess.
Entry.123:
Am orderly Corporal today and have usual duties attached to this duty.

Trainloads of supplies still arrive.

Nothing
un
eventful happened today

Started 1 letter during afternoon

On duty until 9 pm.

Issued with Imperial issue tunic and brass buttons.
Some kits now
Entry.124:
Orderly Sergeant today and a fair amount ot duty too. Responsible for all A.M.C. & A.C.B.F.A. lines in West end of Maascar Isolation camp.

Finished letter started yesteday.

"Old" mail from Australia given out. Mostly interstate men got letters.

Friday 29June 1917.

On no special duty today. Drill during morning and at 1.30 p.m. fell in 
at
 dressed in shorts, shirts & carring our towel
s
 waterbottle
s
, we were taken to one of the Bitter Lakes at Ismalia for a swim.

Crossed a pontoon bridge over a fresh water canal. Arab dowhs in the canal. Went within a mile & ½ of Ferry's Port, Ismailia. Saw 2 native girls. They are very pretty &
nice
peculiar mannered. Had a conversatn. with some natives. Natives came out on the sands while we were dressing & tired to sell their wares but most of us hung shyof them. (Latest) (Aust. mail in Egypt for our unit gone astray).

(Found later that it went to Abbassia
Entry.127:
Parades during morning and none in afternoon. Did some washing after 4 p.m. 1stsince leaving boat. An easy day in this respect.

At 10 pm. detailed with 5 others for a stretcher squad to hospital depot½ way to meet Amb. from Ismailia, with 5 patients. Amb. late – waited 2 hrs in sun with patients and got back to camp at 1.30 pm. & missed dinner. Another stretcher party at 7 p.m. to part of the isolation area.
Entry.128:
Reveille at 6 a.m. & appreciated the 2 hrs. extra
sleep
rest but planes disturbed us from 4 to 6 a.m. Fell in at 9 a.m. & with other units were taken for a swimming parade, to Bitter Lakes. Ismailia. Had a decent swim and several of us bought water melons from natives. They were nearly as good as Australian produce of this kind. Around the lakes are date palms which give the place a fresh appearance. Maize & vegetables are also grown by irrigation.

Reached camp 12.30 pm. & wrote up diary & letters during afternoon.

Monday 2 July 1917.

Reveille 4 a.m. Parade as usual. I am Mess Orderly today. Major Whitford gave us an address on 1stand
Entry.129:
battles of Gaza. I took notes & a copy of his sketches. He has just arrived from the front & is taking up position of Adjutant of A.C.B.F.A.

A trainload of Turkish prisoners came through here from Gaza this morning. 3 hospial trains came through yesterday & today from the front.
Entry.130:
Early morning parades as usual & a march across the desert. 1 mile across & a mile back again.

Crossed country where Australians dug themselves in during defence of canal. In stretcher party to meet Amb. (motor)¼ way to Ismalia.No. 26 Stationary Hospital. Saw grave of Australian
officer
who
was court martialled & shot.
died in the Tel-el Kebir march– ?

Back to camp for dinner of bread & jam & very weak lime juice in water. Several N.C.O's & men arrived from Fd. Amb's
at Gaza
in the field today to take up N.C.O's positions in our unit. 35 Turkish prisoners came down from Gaza with them. Saw Kabeema (Canteen Sgt).

Wrote 2 letters for him to take to Australia & post there. (He never turned up again so the letters never 
went
)
Entry.131:
Usual parades during early morning till 7.30 a.m. Special duties– (stretcher bearing today). Instruction in elementary riding etc. and at
11 p
10.45 a.m. was one of party to water the horses at fresh water canal at back of Ismailia. By time horses were fixed up– groomed etc. & we had marched back to Isolation area it was 2 pm. Parade at 3-30 pm & reallotment oftents. More fooling around & of course in heavy clothes.

More N.C.O's from
Gaza
in the field arrive here.

Saw Johnson N.A.G today (Vic.) L.H.F.A.
Entry.132:
On duty on open rifle range as A.M.C. detail in case of accidents Had an easy day.

1stmail from Australia. I got 7 letters. (3 from home, 1 from Toorak & 1 from Burnley & 2 from Joy. Wrote 1 to Dandenong & posted it).
Entry.133:
Feeling off 
cl
color today. Riding test this morning. Passed alright and in the final allotment for our unit which is to be Imperial Camel Corps Brigade Field AmbulanceI am included in the Bearer Division. G.S.S.Cmrn. also.

Paraded sick tonight and am at present in Hospital (Field Amb.)

A 4 funnelled Cruiser is this morning anchored in the Canal off Ferry's Post at entrance to Bitter Lakes.

Troops are concentrating at Kantara now, Thousands of Tommies have left here for there.
Entry.134:
In hospital. Feeling not too good, but expect to be out in a couple of days.

Another mail in. Got 4 letters. Wrote 2 this afternoon.

A very heavy fog hung to the ground till 7 am. when it lifted. 1st dampness of any description that we have seen in atmosphere since arriving in Egypt.

Feeling worse this afternoon if anything running a temp.
Entry.135:
Still in hospital. Fair this morning.

On the general parade ground all the troops paraded in review order and were splendidly addressed by a Brigadier General (Royston) who has charge of part of the Australian troops in this part of the war. He inspected the men almost individually, and seemed as pleased with the men as the men were with him. In conclusion the troops gave him "3 hearty cheers".
Entry.136:
In hospital.

A biplane was, owing to engine trouble, forced to decend near our lines. Another 
battl
eplane performed a very creditable movement - flew very low, almost pulling up, dropped passenger to give other pilot a hand and flew on. Soon a motor car with repair outfit was on the scene and in an hour the machine was in working order.

50 volunteers for A.M.C. out of A.L.H. Reinfts. Thousands of "Tommies" have now moved out on the way to the Gaza front from the main camp of Moascar.
Entry.137:
In hospital. Feeling pretty good & expect to be out tomorrow. Things as usual in the camp. Rumored that the mail closes tonight so must get to work on the letters.

"Tommy" camp practically empty now. Geo. Cameron got 2 S.B.&M. Journal papers & I read these also "Herald" dated 26th May. Sgt. Browne got "Argus" dated 17th & 26th May & saw these also. Saw where Pat Lynch has died of wounds in hospital in France on May 6th 1917. He was wounded 5 months ago.
Entry.138:
Discharged from hospital at 10 am. No duty today & go back to join my unit tomorrow. The boys in A.C.B.F.A. lines had practice atriding mules.

Paidthis afternoon 3 Egyptian£ notes (In English money£3/1s/7d.)

Wrote 1 letter

10 aeroplanes up this morning.
Entry.139:
With C.B.F.A. once more and attending the parades which are same as before. All supers. were on the mules this morning.

Those 50 AMC. details mentioned previous marched in today & they are real 
wasters
 not up to the standard of Amb. men.

Rumors
 at to where we move "shortly" are started & the no of "furphies" are nearly as bad as Seyr.camp between Jan. & May this year.

Friday 13
Entry.140:
Usual parades and drill etc.

Isolation believed to be lifted tomorrow at midday.

At 4 p.m. we handed in, to Camp Q.M. the following articles :–
1 pr. (mounted service) breeches, 1 tunic (service dress), 2 complete suits dungarees, 1 pr. boots.

Awaiting orders 
of
 for further movements from this camp.

Got particulars from Pte. J. A. Gould, CB. F.A. of "Konigsberg" action on East coast of Africa. He was on the Cruiser "Pioneer". Entered these in front of diary.

(A Chmlion a beautiful specimen found. C.L.B. has it as a pet).
Entry.141:
Early morning parade as usual & as on every other Saturday morning we struck our tents at 5 a.m. to give to tent space an airing. Mess orderly today with "Nat" and then at 9 a.m. fell in for swimming parade to Bitter Lakes. Saw several native women. They are rather good looking and that's all.

Hospital boat "Niagra" & a Br Cruiser in the Canal (Suez)

On return pitched tents. (This was 
good
 in the midday sun too.).

Wrote a letter later.

Sun 15thWe visited the Spanish, Greek, French & European quarters and were pleased to see some people who reminded us of home.
Entry.142:
Church parade this morning fell out crook and at 1 p.m. leave given to go into Ismalia (as we understood.)

6 of us hired a "gharry" and were driven through the streets of Ismailia. It was very interesting to us as everything was quite new to our 
mi
nds
 ideas.

Coming back we were stopped by guard on the bridge entering Ismailia on the Tel-el-Kebir –Nafisha Rd. Marched back to Isolation Area under an armed guard with bayonets fixed. 1 guard to 2 men. Classed (
by officers
) as prisoners & placed under open arrest.

Turned in early feeling crook as I was when I fell out on church parade. Leave was 2 p.m. till 5.30 pm. "Gaggat" & the "Boy" were clinked in Ismailia.

Monday 16 July 1917.

Still feeling crook but went on the riding test and mounted drill. At the remount depot we saw some beautiful exhibitions of buckjumping.

Weighed myself on QM's scales at R. Depot and was 9 st. 12 lbs.

Have dropped weight owing to being crook the last fortnight.

"Gaggat & the Boy" released from close custody

For those who wanted leave there was leave given for 3 hrs to go to Moascar. I never troubled it.

Posted up that those who were under open arrest have been released as it was a mistake that we got into Ismailia on Sunday afternoon.

Met "Sid Glover" who is now in Details camp.
Entry.143: biplane wrecked at Aerodrome and pilot killed.
Entry.144:
Riding again this morning on mules. A little amusement also. A heavy fog hung over the desert for 3 hrs this morning.

Nearly all the A.M.C. Details & L.H.F.A. Reinfts in Isolation area are leaving 
for Gaza
 tomorrow morning at 1.30 from this camp. Several of them put their names etc in my autograph album.

They moved off at 8 pm from our lines and are to leave Moascar station at 1.30 am tomorrow morning for "up the line".
Entry.145:
On the mules again this morning. Thrown straight away but tackled another & got through the morning with him. They are obstinate "pig headed" animals. Handed in my name at 11 a.m. for leave to Moascar this evening.

Tent orderly again today. Wrote up some post card views of Ismailia.

Went on leave to Moascar main camp reported back at 9.15 pm. All troops in Isolation area being inoculated against Cholera & Para Typhoid tonight up till 1 a.m. tomorrow morning.

Guard taken off with exception of real Iso. guard. Quarantine flags taken away also from main camp.
Entry.146:
Reveille 7 a.m. No parade until 9.15 after breakfast. Appreciated late rising.

Inoculated against Cholera & Para-typhoid at 11 a.m.

Wrote letters during afternoon to Home & D'nong.

24 hrs light duty for those inoculated.
Entry.147:
Reveille 7 a.m. Another good sleep in. Still no duties for those inoculated.

At 1 pm left this area with others on leave to Ismailia 1 pm to 9.30 pm. It was Christmas Day in this country. Queer & quaint sights were to be seen. Had conversation with Indian troops, one a Sgt Redigul 58 Rifles V.C. hero. Took a snap of them in Rue Negrelli. Returned to camp at 8.30 pm.

Got 9 letters by mail that had been given out while on leave. Read them over hurriedly before "lights out". Cpl. Brennan 4th A.L.H. 7th Regt. had called to see me about George Kelley.

The European population came out of doors towards evening in Ismailia.
Entry.148:
Reveille 4 a.m. & straight on to the mules again. Struck a better one this morning.

No parade during afternoon.

Washed some clothes and printed photos.
Entry.149:
Reveille 6 am. Duty Stretcher Squad (
a member
). Went on Swimming Parade to Bitter Lakes Ismailia.

Printed photos during afternoon.

No church parade as the Chaplains have gone to Cairo a week ago.

Monday 23
Entry.150:
Up at 4 a.m. Riding mules again.

Action on Gaza front warming up
.

Arrival of our new Q.M. (Lt.) Phillips

Printed & fixed photos of the "Boorara" trip.
Entry.151:
Reveille as usual. No riding on mules this morning as they are being inoculated.

Received local papers from home and "Bulletin" from Joy.

Kantara was bombed by a Turkish taube last night so report goes. Hardly creditable.

Rumors as to marching out.

Went to main Moascar Camp to see 99 Cpl. H. J. Brennan 4 A.L.H. who called about G. Kelley last Friday afternoon.

Never saw him.
Entry.152:
No riding this morning but swimming parade instead, and on return to camp were marched back through Nafisha and Nefiche.

The "Tommy" Howitzer Battery is preparing to move out and our unit has now been issued with 24 hrs. rations (iron) as the A.S.C. Depot has moved this morning.

Inoculated again against Para-typhoid (a double dose.)
Entry.153:
6 o'clock reveille again this morning. A little fatigue work preparing to move out of camp. Light Horse moved out to Details Camp at Moascar.

Wrote to D'nong (Sigd. green O.A.S. envelope with snap of Doris (Imperial) enclosed and posted same at Post Office in Moascar Camp.)

Found later that such snaps are not permissable, that was the reason why I added the bracketed note above to protect myself should anything arise about it later.
Entry.154:
6 am reveille.

Read out in orders that the action I took regarding the letter yesterday is contrary to censorship.

Notified that tomorrow we move out to Abbassia & the list of men to go read out on parade. I am included in original crowd.

Boys having a blow out tonight & the bulk of them merry celebrating the moving out to Abbassia.
Entry.155:
Feeling crook this morning. Reveille 4 a.m. Breakfast 6 a.m. Baggage guard on wagon & left at 7.30 a.m. to Moascar Station. The rest of C.B.F.A. came along later. Entrained at 10.20 a.m. Arrived at Cairo and disentrained at ¼ to 2 p.m.

Baggage guard again out to Main Abbassia Camp. Nigger driver tried to take me down. Feeling all 
all
 out to it.

All the way along tlhe railway line the fields are highly cultivated & as the result beautiful crops are on the land. Saw guns used by Napoleon and in the distance saw Pyramids.

2 of the boys L.H.F.A. who left a week or so ago have come to grief – 1 killed & 1 wounded sowe hear.
Entry.156:
Reveille 7 a.m. Planes kept us awake from 4 a.m. Still as we were tired we appreciated the extra rest.

Egyptian troops drilling in our 
troops
camp. Muster parade & lecture by Lt Colonel. 25% got leave.

Harry Flavell & I went to 14 AGH. Saw Ted Holden (Sgt), Tom de Gruchy, Chas Hirsefield, Jim Tatterson. Heard that McKinnon has been mentioned in despatches.
Entry.157:
Reveille 5 a.m. With the camels this morning for the first time.

Wrote letter to Olive & got ready to go on leave to Cairo. I am Mess Orderly today.
Entry.158:
With the camels again this morning. Went on leave to Cairo last night and going again tonight. A wonderful sight and places to be seen "as old as the hills".

Saw old castle where slaves were sold in early days. This place now used for military purposes. The staging of the gallows still remains & old blood stains are still to be seen.
Entry.159:
The camels again. After breakfast equipment fixed up for 4 hrs. march into desert.

In Cairo again last night. Went to Anzac Hostel, Y.M.C.A. & Br. Soldiers Home. It was a pleasure to be served with supper in the Y.M.C.A. in Esbekia Gardens, by the British ladies who were very polite.

A biplane came to grief within 30 yds of our section this morningPilot escaped with his life. Machine smashed to pieces.

Pilot died later from shock
. (1/5/18) CCF
Entry.160:
The camels again. After breakfast equipment fixed up for 4 hrs march into the Desert tomorrow.

During evening a party of us went to Heliopolis. Saw right through Luna Park for 5 P.T. & then went up through the principle streets. The buildings are beautiful & the latest type having been rebuilt during the last 10 yrs. Prior to this these buildings were some of the oldest in the world.
Entry.161:
Reveille 4 a.m. Saddle up camels & setoff. A round-about kind of a march it was. Country in places limestone hills. These hills were very steep & camels advanced in single file till we reached the top.

(Breakfast 9 am.)

We passed beside the old city of Cairo & near "The Citadel".

Leave from 4 pm till 9.30 p.m.

Got wristlet watch from jeweller 1st repair.

Saw a stylish French funeral in Cairo and snapped it.
Entry.162:
5 am reveille this morning and 
grooming only
 before breakfast.

After 9 am parade. –Saddle 
cleaning
 and general equipment cleaning.

Wrote letters in afternoon.
Entry.163:
7 a.m. Reveille. No riding this morning on the camels. At 2 pm. a party of 15 of us went for the afternoon to see the Pyramids. The tramride (electric) was great & the views across the intensely cultivated fields were interesting. Saw Egyptians ploughgwith the old wooden ploughand 2 oxen. On arrival at the Pyramids we hired a donkey each & with a guide saw all that there is to be seen; visiting all the pyramids sphinx, old & new tombs & seeing through the temples of sphinx & interior of the largest pyramid
s
. Had tea at Y.M.C.A. in Cairo & reached Abbassia Camp at 9.30 pm.
Entry.164:
No holiday here though.

On the camels once more. We are getting a little used to them by now.

During afternoon went to 14 A.G.H. to see Ted Holden (Sgt) & Tom de Gruchy. While there saw several of the other boys on the Staff & as patients there.

After tea & feeding parade went to Cairo with H. Flavell.

Back for "tattoo" roll call at 9.30 pm at camp.

Made a few purchases in 
the
 part of the "Mouske"
Entry.165:
Instruction in full marching order for the field where it appears we will move out to shortly.

To Cairo in evening to have envelopes containing silkhandkerchiefs censored at Anzac Hostel. Had to leave them there till tomorrow.

Supper at Y.M.C.A. & back to camp.

During afternoon we were issued with the rest of our equipment for the field & had to fill water tanks & dhurra bags for tomorrow.
Entry.166:
Saddled up straight away in marching order and went for an hours jaunt.

Washing & grooming parade then to water & back to feed.

Arranged to have the name of Regtlpaper changed from Stretcher to "Cacelot", and a concert with outside & 14 A.G.H. artists is being arranged in our huts for Friday evening.

Another attempt to finish a letter to D'nong and finished it too.

Went on leave to Cairo & regdthree envelopes with handkerchiefs enclosed.

Met Mal Jamieson 3rd L.H.F.A. who is down from 
Gaza
 the line for 7 days leave.
Entry.167:
Camels in marching order & a trot round the hills near camp. Finished up early this morning at 10.45 a.m.

At 2 p.m. went to 14 A.G.H. to see the boys.

Went to Cairo on leave with Ted Holden & Tom de Gruchy. Had tea in Cairo & then a tram ride to the Citadel just about dusk. Came back to city & went to Groppe's & Liptons & back to camp at 9.45 pm.

Saw where one hole was made & damage done by aeroplane raid by Turks last November on Cairo. Since then the Turks have been driven back 125 miles.
Entry.168:
Usual routine before breakfast & after breakfast sadde cleaning & watering camels.

Detailed for picquet for 24 hrs from 6 p.m. tonight.

Printed photos.

Posted as 2nd relief on guard from 8 till 10 pm. but managed to work it so that I could see the concert, which was a success too.
Entry.169:
On picquet 2 a.m. till 4 a.m,Sudanese on picquet also. 
Told me that the
 They were excited as raiding Bedouins had cut 1 camel loose & taken it out into the desert.

Next post 8 am. till 10 am.

Printed & fixed photos & wrote letters.

Next post 2 p.m. till 4 p.m.

Whole picquet relieved at 6 p.m.

Had a shower & turned in at 8 p.m.

Sunday 12th (continued)

Mail delivered today. I received 8 letters. Only 1 of my Colombo letters received.

Sunday 12th (continued)

shot as a spy 2 months ago. Bloodstains still on tree & ashes of burnt clothing nearby. Grave not far away.

Saw Marmaluke's leap and chipped pieces of Alabasta off back of Mohammed Ali Mosque.
Entry.170:
Up at 6.45 am. Feed up parade at 7.45 am. Breakfast 8.15 a.m.

Watering camels 10.45 a.m.

Went on leave to Cairo and Citadel at 2 p.m.

Saw through the Sultan Hassan Mosque which was bombarded by Napoleon from Citadel in 1880 & a cannon ball is still sticking in the wall. Where the other balls struck can be seen by marks on the wall.

Went through the Blue Mosque & to the top of the minaret where we could see right over Cairo. Took 2 snaps. Then to the Citadel. Guard took our cameras from us at main entrance. Saw through the Mohammed Ali Mosque. Most beautiful Mosque in Egypt.

Saw Joseph's well 320 ft deep & tree where an Egyptian Sgt Major was
Entry.171:
Inspection in drill order & camels in marching order by Colonel Buxton at 6.30 a.m. Result not too good.

Finished grooming after breakfast at 10.15 a.m.

Mess orderly today.

Went on leave to Cairo at 5 pm. & back at 10 p.m.
Entry.172:
Drill order only with camels before breakfast. Posted Registered Parcel to Mother.

Received "Table Talk" from Joy this afternoon.

Had snap taken on camel this afternoon.

After feeding parade went to Cairo & got photographic material for taking "up the line".

Tonight the light saving action came into force & it makes a difference to Cairo city.

Wednesday 15 August 1917.

Usual routine this morning.

Had a fall & have a bandaged arm & crook back as the result.

Received "The Bulletin" from Joy and 1st parcel from home.

Everybody in different spirits this afternoon.

On account of arm was not on night 
wo
rk
Entry.173:
tonight. 

Wrote letters instead. 

Printed photos this morning.
Entry.174:
Heard that mail for Australia closes today. Posted letter
s
.

Paraded with arm which has turned septic. Put on no duty & treatment. Had arm dressed at 5 pm at Convalescent Depot and went on leave to Cairo to get more camera supplies for taking up the line.

Wrote home this afternoon.

Friday 17 August 1917.

On no duty & treatment again today.

Received marching orders for the firing line. All kits for base packed & on the wagon by 10 a.m. & taken away to Base Depot.

Went to 14 A.G.H. & said goodbye to Ted Holden & Tom de Gruchy. Met Ern Harris in Hosp. again 2nd time down from
Entry.175:
L.H.F.A. (In going through kit thought I had lost 
your
 some photos. Found them later). Went to bed at 9 am. & ready for TOMORROW.
Entry.176:
Reveille 3.45 am. Blankets kit etc. loaded on wagon 4.10 am. Breakfast 4.15. Fall in with equipment & dressed in puttees & shorts & drill tunics at 5 am. Check roll call. Marched to Abbassia tram. Boarded tram & arrived Cairo Rly Stn. at 6.15 Unloaded baggage & entrained 7 a.m. Arrived Zsgazig at 8.25. Tel El Kabir 9.45. Ismailia 10.45. Kantara 11.20. Disentrained & marched to Rest camp 2 miles & had small lunch.

Had a little look round Kantarracamp. Hundreds of troops preparing to move out tonight for firing line. A mere snack for tea & slept on sand till 10 p.m. Kits put on M.T. wagon at 10.40 pm. In marching order fell in & marched to Kantara East Stn. Placed in trucks (open) & 30 to 1 truck & train moved off at 11.25 p.m. Threw our gear down & in an uncomfortable & tangled heap tried to sleep but it was impossible. Train jolted & bumped all through the night.
Entry.177:
Gave up trying to sleep at 4 a.m. Had a little hard rations & water. Are now passing over captured ground & through stations built by Allies on occupatn.

Every mile or so there is a redoubt on a sandridge and surrounded by barb & springwire entanglements. Soldiers graves often seen here &there near Stations.

Arrived 7.40 a.m. at No 4 Staty Hosplon shores of the Mediterranean Sea. Hosp. not yet staffed as it is new. First sighed Medit. Sea at 7 a.m. Rly line follows shore now.

Arrived El Arish 8.45 am. Left 9.30 a.m. & crushed still more in trucks round meat boxes.H
ead for open desert
. Passed through fortified & entrenched country. Taube flew over at 10 a.m.

Arrived Raffa 11.15. ShiekhNuran at 12.20 (due at 12.17 pm) Transferred our kit on camels to Scottish Horse Amb. bivouac at 2.30 pm. Light ration at 3 p.m. & at 3.30 started to build our own bivouacs. Bully & bread ration for tea. At dusk watched from a distance an aerialengagement. Shells seenbursting round the 6 planes up.

Guns on Gaza front heard plainly through the night.
Entry.178:
Reveille 5 a.m. Breakfast 6 a.m. Stayed in dugout all day nothing doing. Guns rather quiet today and bivouac camp quiet also.

We are now behind the firing line at last and in sound of the guns.
Entry.179:
Reveille 4.45 a.m. Fall in 5. a.m. Detailed in a party of 6 men, one N.C.O & one Capt. to go to Maleleh Beach at back of Raffa to relieve the Scottish Horse Amb special detachment there. Breakfast 6 am.
Moved off from Shiekh Nuran with camels in full marching order at 7.30 a.m. Passed thousands of troops bivouaced on the desert. Struck railway line at 8.25 & then treked for some miles following this line. At 10.30 arrived at Raffa. Got supplies at canteen.
Left Raffa 11 am. & followed track across the sand dunes to beach at back of Raffa arriving there at 1.10 p.m. My camel knocked up 1½ miles from end of trek & I had to walk & lead him. Relieved Sch Hrse who left at 4 a.m. Took over.
Nothing doing. Went in for 1st dip in Mediterranean Sea. Had tea & turned in– Thousands of troops are resting here on the beach with animals and all equipment.
Entry.180:
No reveille here Turned out at 6 am. Fed camels. One of the party is doing the cooking. Breakfast 7 a.m. At 8.30 all went for an hr. in the surf. Watered camels at 10 a.m.Dinner 12 noon. Fed camels at 1 pm.Drew rations at 2 pm and then washed some clothes.

Went for a dip at 4.30. p.m. and another at 6.30 p.m.

(The amateur cook tried to make a custard but put salt in place of sugar.) (Result– a failure.)

Yesterday we passed Italian troops holding fortified sandhills & redoubts, also passed several graveyards each holding 20 to 30 bodies of men killed in the Rafa stunts.
Entry.181:
Turned out at 6.30 am. Breakfast 7 a.m.Not feeling quite up to the mark I never went into the surf this morning.

At 3.30 pm. a Taube came over but the anti-aircraft guns fired16 shells at her and she flew back again, apparently unharmed.

Wrote 2 letters. One home & one to D'nong

Had tea & after a dip turned in.
Entry.182:
Turned out at 7 a.m. Fed camels and later on took them for a dip in the surf. The breakers bowled a couple of them over. Saddled up after breakfast
and
watered camels, & filled "fantasies"

Did a little more washing.

Allied planes keeping a good watch over us today. Troops moving out from, & others moving in to the beach rest camp.
Entry.183:
Nothing much doing. Tonsilitis seems to be prevalent among troops off the desert. 5 patients went to Raffa this morning. 3 Br. planes above all day. No rations.

(The last few days a number of boats are to be seen on the water horizon every evening, apparently on their way to Port Said.)

Ammunisiton barges were being brought up this morning at no distance from shore, to the dump at Beelah 6 miles from here towards the line.
Entry.184: Out at 6.15 am. "Wallad" fed camels at 6 and saved me trouble. Breakfast 7.30 a.m. Filled "fantasies" and watered camels by 11 a.m. Dinner 12.30 pm. Afternoon nothing doing
Entry.185:
Very little doing nevertheless a good deal of fooling round with one thing and another.

Swum the camels again this morning before 7 a.m.

Expect to be relieved tomorrow.

Wrote letters.
Entry.186:
Turned out as usual. (No relief today)

At 10 am. left Malaleh Beach with 8 patients for Rafa. 4 for 74th C.C.S. and 4 for 65th C.C.S.

Arrived Rafa at 12. noon. C.C.Sns at 12.20p.m. Handed patients over and made way back. Saw some of the boys. Got lastest news. Arrived Beach at our detachment at 4.25 pm

On the way to Rafa passed a Field Battery 4.7 inch guns guarding line in case of a flank attack. Saw several graveyards of soldiers killed in Rafa stunt, also the main Turkish Redoubt which took a day to capture & with it was taken 1800 prisoners. At this place –German Officers & N.C.O's. were in charge of Turks & when Turks surrendered Gern N.C.O's turned M.G's on the Turks.

Loaded Hosp. train passed through Rafa

Wednesday 29 August 1917.

Very little doing today.

3 Taubes shelled in vicinity of Sheikh Nuran.

Heard mail closed today or rather last night; & from all reports all letters written between 6thJune &
Entry.187:
July never reached Australia therefore up to this date in Austlia they have have received no word by letter of our arrival.

Anxiously awaiting our mail which we cannot get until relieved.

Living in hopes that those mails were not lost at sea. General disheartening regarding this.
Entry.188:
Nothing out of the ordinary today except that bombardment on Gaza is still continuing with the same energy. This started at 1 a.m. this morning. This evening at 9.30 the shrapnel shells could be seen bursting over the trenches. "Very" lights were also plainly seen

Expect relief tomorrow.
Entry.189:
Bombardment still continues with same vigour. Exceptionally strong at times. Had a dip before breakfast.Sewing in afternoon

No relief today. Relief expected now on Sunday.
Entry.191:
Turned out at 5 am & straight into sea for a dip. We are leaving here this morning.

At 11.15 am. had everything packed up, and ourselves & camels in full marching order. left Malaleh Beach at 11.30 a.m. & treked to Rafa. Got few stores. Then through to Shiekh Nuran arriving there at 5.30 pm. (Times 11.15 a.m.
to
2 pm. 5.20 p.m.)
Sudanese
Egyptians unsaddled camels & we after a light tea turned in as best we could as "boarders" in some of the dugouts for the night.

Most impt thing– got 12 letters that were waiting here a week for me. "Good, oh"!
Entry.192:
Reveille5 a.m. Turned out and ready to groom by 5.15 am. Breakfast 6.30 a.m. (Smaller ration than at Malaleh Beach)Turned camels out to graze at 9.30 a.m. Feed up
& stables
at 3.30 pm.

Issued with & instructions in use of P.D Gas helmet respirator 4 till 5 pm.Tea, a wash & turned in.

During today I dug in with L/Cpl Watson. Made a plain & comfortable dugout too.

It is now a Military Standing Order in this country behind the firing line
that every man must be quartered in a dugout.
Entry.193:
Nothing much doing this morning till 10 a.m. Left shortly after for watering parade
at
to the Waddy 7 miles distant. Passed over ground wntrenched the by Turks and underground stables etc. of theirs. The Waddy is a creek that flows in a valley it has made for itself through countless years. The erosion each rainy season can be seen on the "banks".

On the way we passed the old fort used by the Crusaders in their wars in Palestine. 12-15 miles lower down the Waddy Ghuzzi, the Turks hold it.

Detailed & fell in for picquet at 6.30 pm. for the 
1st
next 24 hrs
Wrot
Struck 1stpost
on picquet
.
Entry.194:
Sports today at Shiekh
Narang
 Nuranand to be concluded
tomorrow
Friday. A Taube came over about 11 am. & although shelled from all directions escaped unharmed to his own lines. Wrote letters in time between reliefs on the picquet. Did first lot of cooking– a success too.

Boys returned from Marakeb Beach, & another detachment went to take their place (Tent Division.)
Entry.195:
Reveille 5 a.m.

At tent inspection at 9 a.m. in the "dugout" bivouac competition my "Terra Domus" got honorable mention.

Handed over patients from Sandcart to Hospital Train at Shiekh Nuran (dump) station. On the camels for watering parade to the "Waddy" at10 a.m. Back at 4.30 pm. Fooled about by a lecture & tea at 5 pm. Next to no dinner & no wash all day, no time since morning when breakfast & wash had to be had in 5 minutes.
Entry.196:
On cooks 
fatigue
assistant and worked all day from 5 a.m. till 7 pm. on it too. A crook day.

The fnal of the sports events came off today. A party of our unit made "a book" and came off with£27 to the good.
Entry.197:
Out at 5 a.m. as usual. Grooming and feeding as usual.

Gas parade at 7.30 am. in full kit for½ hr.

Generally fooled around till midday. A little time to myself later in day.

My dugout companion has gone to Malaleh Beach on duty. Have "Terra Domus" to myself now.
Entry.198:
Quartermasters fatigue today & various duties entailed by that fatigue.

"Again a little more time to myself"
A wonder.

Reported that the Taube that came over the other day was brought down near the Waddy.

Another Taube over again this morng. Anti-aircraft guns gave him a hot time. As usual the British planes appeared when he was gone.

Bombardment on the line today.

Water issue 2 
pints
 bottles for washing drinking etc. Total allowed by G.R.O. 2 pts. per man per day. This water comes right from Kantara. Is pumped from there.

Geo. Kelley at last came actoss me after being baffled so many times.

Monday 10 September 1917.
