Routine as usual till 9 a.m. Cleaning, restuffing & fitting saddles all day & in the sun & dust with 1¼ hrs for lunch. A solid day again. Heard that another Australian mail landed at Suez 2 days ago. Everybody waiting for same.

Tuesday 11 September 1917.

Taubes visited us several times today, and were shelled. "Poor shooting"

Detailed for guard duty tonight till 6.30 p.m. tomorrow night.

Saddle repairing again all the day.

1stpost on
guard
picquet duty on camel lines

Wednesday 12 September 1917.

On
guard
picquet duty 1stpost.

As it was watering day there was not such a great deal doing as regards
guard
picquet on the lines.

Relieved 6.30 pm.

New
Detachment at Malaleh Beach returned.

Thursday 13 September 1917.

Usual routine & saddle repairning.

2 Taubes over this morning for an hour. Flew out of range of anti aircraft guns.

Capt. McCredie went to 4thBattalion. as R.M.O.

Friday 14 September 1917.

On water fatigue. On the way I killed a snake 3 ft. long
this morning
on the desert.

Those who had not been to the beach went this morning in full gear at 9.30
pm
a.m.

2 Taubes over again.

Saturday 15 September 1917.

On QM's fatigue today & missed the watering trip to the Waddy. Not sorry either.(One camel having died is struck off the strength.) "Orders". (What next!!)

One taube over this morning.

Boys returned from 
Marakeb
 Malaleh Beach. Went short way & had a good time. Had 24 hrs. on the beach.

No Australian mail yet.

Wrote 1 letter.

Sunday 16 September 1917.

1 Taube over this morning. Went to Church Parade. The first time since leaving Moascar Isolation Camp. The rest of the day very little doing.

At the Aerodrome ½ mile from our position things are going ahead and very busy too.

No Aust. mail yet.

Received parcel from Ted Holden from 14 A.G.H.

Monday 17 September 1917.

Biplanes coming to new Aerodrome in large numbers 
th
 today. All new machines too.

Duties:- Despatch rider for week.

It is said that the Aerodrome is being opened today.

3rd & 4th Brigade on the rising ground towards Marakeb start to move out to the other side of the "Waddy".

Wrote a couple of letters.
Entry.199:
On despatch messenger once again and today a deal of fooling aroundbusiness. (Mismanagement again.) A busy day & late into evening also.

The dust today is terriffic, the worst day in this respect since arriving in Egypt.

At 8.30 when I took latest despatches to Brigade Hd Qrs the searchlignts of ours (Allies) could be plainly seen sweeping everywhere.

3rd &
Entry.200:
Brigades moved out to the other side of Tel-el-Farah on the Waddy. Gazzeh. Moving all day.

Geo. Kelley called on the way out with
Entry.202: Brigade. I was out again on duty and missed him.
Entry.203:
On the go again. As regards the number of despatches – a good day; – the dust – a rotten day, even worse than yesterday.

Received F.C. Card & letter from Clarrie in France.
Entry.206:
An uneventful day with the exception of 2 Taubes over and a row I had with the Orderly Room people on account of being crook. They tried to make out that I was malingeering. Thats is all the thanks I got for carrying out my duties satisfactorily.

Friday 21
Entry.207:
4 Taubes over this morning and things livening up on the front by the sound of the guns. His Taube monoplanes can travel some – too fast to be shelled with any effect by our guns.

One of his machines had some narrow escapes.
Entry.208:
(Reveille at 5.30 a.m. ½ hr later than usual.)

A very busy day for me on despatch. (Unnecessary trips.)

2 Taubes & rather low. Escaped our guns.
Entry.209: Duties kept me from church parade.
Entry.210: Taube over today. Easy day on despatch to some of the other days and nights.
Entry.211: Usual routine this morning. Off despatch rider duties, and missed watering parade so had an easy day.
Entry.212:
Taube over.

Won writing pad (Red Cross)
Entry.214:
Taube today came over & immediately he was gone up went our planes as usual.

Accident at aerodrome.

R.F.C. from Ismailia moving into same grounds as the Australian aerodrome here at Shiekh Nuran. An active fighting unit on arrival.
Entry.215:
An accident at aerodrome.

Biplanes & battle planes are being tested daily.

One Taube visited us today.
Entry.216:
On watering parade to the Waddi 6 miles out. Since my last visit, things have changed wonderfully. "The line of communication" is altogetlher improved in every way. Telegraph lines, entrenched roads etc. form a great change & addition to the defences. There are now thousands of troops on the Waddi in expectation of the "big push" shortly.

Artillery covered by battle
aero
planes was seen moving out towards flank of 
Beersheebah
 Beersheba.

(Printed photos between 9 & 10 am)
Entry.218:
Very little doing. Biplanes from R.F.C. Fighting Squadron "looped the loop several times this morning

"Jacko" over again.
Entry.219:
Reveille 5 a.m. Stables 5.25. Breakfast 6 a.m.

Church parade & presentation of medals to 6 O/R. including from A.C.F.A. W.O. Robinson, Sgt. Brennan, Staff Sgt Lumb.

"Jacko" sent tworepresentatives today.

Took a couple of snaps.
Entry.220:
1 Taube appeared and chased 2 of our planes out of sight. As soon as they were gone 2 of our planes went up 
very daring
. (
I don't think
.)

Inspection today by A.D.M.S. The Lt Col & "Gagget" made a bosh of the whole affair. Result – Instructional parades from this on.
Entry.221:
First instructional parade for some time, & under Major Whitford. 
and
It was satisfactory.

Printed photos & fixed other prints 40 in all. Good results.
Entry.223:
Taubes over at10.30 a.m. Persisted in their reconnoitering and shelled very closely at times. Hundreds of shells fired at them. At times when over our position they flew low, pieces of shell landing in our lines and roundabout.

As shells burst the pieces sang through the air above our heads. All took to dugouts. Natives frightened out of their wits. Expect air raid tonight from all accounts.
Entry.224:
Jacko never put in an appearance today until late. (As he comes every day now I've decided not to note every time he comes.)

Australian mail 6th since arriving in Egypt. Small mail which closed in Australia on July 19th week later that previous mail but took 7 weeks longer to reach here.

(One letter that I expected never arrived.)

Received 6 letters and packet of local papers.

Friday 5 October 1917.

Main note on opposite page (lower half.)
Entry.225:
On watering parade at 0700 and back at 1100. View "no mans" land today from the Waddi. Position now.

No man's land is patrolled by Light Horse patrols.
Entry.227:
Bringing up supplies from Rafa. Got a little bushed as night came on before we got in sight of Aerodrome on return. Struck an outpost & he put us on our track & supplies were got through safely.

On return delighted to find another Australian mail (direct) 8 letters & packet of local papers.

One of our battle planes brought down a Taube this morning.

Geo. S.S. Cameron back from Marakeb beach with Archie Scott.
Entry.229:
"Bill" Abel transferred to No 2 A.S.Hosp.

Odd fatigues.

Wrote letters.

Very dusty.
Entry.230:
October 1917.

Nothing particular. Warned for picquet tonight for foll. 24 hrs.

Wrote letters.
Entry.231:
On picquet.

Cpl. Heatherington left for 14 A.G.H. ill will (Bilharziosis),contracted in either Egypt or Palestine:

Chas. Barrett also to same base wlith "dangue" or a mild form of "Nile fever" which is becomong prevalent.
Entry.232:
Full dress parade with camels & ourselves in full marching order. Inspection by O.C.

"Jacko" has not been over for a day or so.

Had a narrow escape from being killed tonight at the aerodrome after having seen through the R.F.C. section of it.

A.C.F.AFootball team played A.F.Con Aerodrome football ground & were beaten in the last quarter.
Entry.233:
On water fatigue.

Monday (continued)
down the other day. Pilot & machine smashed to atoms. Pilot being unrecognizable but identification disc showed him to be a N.C.O. & not an officer. His machine fell just inside our lines at Gaza.
Entry.234:
On watering parade.

In afternoon at 4.45 pm. "Jacko" came over & was shelled and returned to his own land. Another Taube appeared and one of our battle planes went up to meet him. The fight lasted 5 mins. for position; a machine gun rang out and one of the planes nose dived and then tumbled like a feather over & over towards earth:½ way down an explosion occurred in the machine and then with smoke coming from her she fell right to earth.

The victor planed down a little to make sure if machine & pilot & observer were done & then made off. The victor to us is at present a ?

Latest news 8.30 pm. Taube brought down by same Flt Officer that brought the Taube
Entry.235:
Tuesday and all day too.

On cook's fatigue.

Geo. Kelley came over from Tel-el-Fara. Stayed for tea & left at 6.30 p.m.

This is the last time I saw George Kelley (C.C.F. 2/5/18)
Entry.236:
25 Reinforcements arrived today from Moascar where they left a couple of days ago.

Some of them who came to Egypt on the "Wiltshire" have not been off the boat a fortnight yet, and are up here at the front already.

Gas parade at 3 p.m.
Entry.237:
Warned for picquet.

General fixing up of things.

Made
 Had new camel whip made for me.
Entry.238:
Preparing for moving out on stunt.

"Iron" - 5 days ration issued.

On picquet today. Relieved at 6 p.m.

Everything busy.
Entry.239:
Announced that we are to move out "sometime tomorrow" and for this, preparations are in progress. Packing up etc.

It is surprising what gear we have accumulated for the 8 or 9 weeks we have been here at Shiekh Nuran.
Entry.240:
Fell in at 2 pm & saddled up with all our gear, equipment etc & 5 days rations. Thousands of troops are on the move.

The whole of the Imperial Camel Brigade in Palestine and the A.C.Fd Amb. are on the move where we do not know but only have an idea.

Halted & formed up at 4.30 p.m 5 miles from Shiekh Nuran. Moved off at 5 p.m. and travelled right through 
the
 till midnight. No smoking or lights of any description and no noise whatever allowed.
Entry.241:
Still on the move and riding the whole time with the exception of a few halts for 5 mins. or so, every 1 or 2 hrs.

Crossed 
the
 large Waddy at 3 pm and at 3.30 am halted & lay on the ground and snatched a little sleep till dawn. When dawn broke, moved to a protected position 
in a ho
 surrounded by hills. Prepared a little bit of something to eat.

Stayed at this position till 11 p.m.

Saddled up and under cover of dark the whole Brigade moved on till midnight.

Abugahylum was the name of this halting place.
Entry.242:
Still on the move and travelled till 4 a.m. most of the time through enemy country when hardly a sound was heard. (None allowed) Lay down when we halted at 4 a.mand slept till dawn & were awakened by an explosion of a mine of the engineers sinking a well.

Camped in the waddy and prepared a rough meal which we cooked ourselves. Our position is 
near
 on the left Sth East flank of Birsheebah & 5 miles from the front Turkish trenches. Bedouins captured.

Near the ruins of an old city built ages ago by King Constantine 1600 yrs 
ago
 B.C.
Entry.243:
On picquet all day and night.

"Stand to" at 3.30 in morning ready for emergencies until the patrols report "all clear" – off saddle & prepare breakfast.
Entry.244:
Awaiting in case of an enemy attack at "Stand to"

On watering
 Watered camels.

Saw families of Bedouins with their flocks and herds watering at the Waddy. A picturesque sight undoubtedly.

A mail as late as Sept 3rd to hand. 8 letters I received.

Malgo
 Maalaga was the watering place.

Wrote Home to Joy.
Entry.245:
Taube flew low & bombed us.

Casualties2 camels & 1 native by one bomb thrown at the H Qrs & Brigade officers. It landed 30 yds from them but they were uninjured although 80 yds away 1 camel was killed. Fantasis (water) near were riddled with holes.

Rifle fire altered his course & thus other bombs fell in open country.

Taubes visited us again during day and bombs had no effect on our position (We have all got "Taubitis" now)

On picquet all day and night. Got several pieces of bomb in bomb crater.

Visited the old ruins & took snaps of graves and some skeletons that were taken from an ancient well.
Entry.246:
Jacko over again but dropped no bombs on our position.

On picquet all day.

Received moving orders at 2 pm & at 4.30 pm moved from Khalasa. Night came on & 
Turks & our
 Light Horse engaged Turks on our right while the Imperial Camel Brigade moved out and the Light Horse Brigade moved in. The Camel Brigade were the first troops to occupy Khalasa. The Turks had evacuated it 3 weeks previously & up to this time it had been patrolled by Aust. Lht Hrs patrol.

Moved all night till midnight when a thunderstorm caught us. Halted & stood to till dawn.

Received 18 letters by another 2 mails that had gone to Engd
Entry.247:
On again at dawn travelled all day till 2 pm when we reached a point between Shiekh Nuran Stn & Shellal. Camel Brigade 
Brigade
 bivouacked.
and


Another batch of 18 letters I received by 2 lots of mail that must have gone to Engdbefore coming to Egypt. This is good, oh!

On picquet tonight.
Entry.248:
Picquet today.

Tonight a very nice letter to hand from Joy. Dated Sept 4th. Wrote a reply.

Expect to be in the thick of the fighting within 48 hrs at Beersheba 
to right of Gaza between Gaza and Beersheebah


Went to confession tonight.
Entry.249:
Posted letter.

Watered camels.

Moved out at 5 pm sharp & commenced a trek till midnight.

(Wed 31st Oct continued.)
Beersheebah by our guns.

2 redoubts have fallen and at 2 pm B–h may fall as our artillery fire is very effective.

Taweil-el-Habair is the hill from which we watched the bombardment and behind which the collecting station was.

H Qrs also dug in there.

Wednesday 31October 1917.

2 am found the Imperial Cml Brigade and other Brigades of Light Horse, Batteries etc. 2½ miles from Turkish lines in the hills defending Beersheebah. A little firing going on but not much at midnight.

Bombardment commenced at dawn and is going the whole time. On each side of our collecting station are batteries of our big guns, which keep the shelling going.

Camels & all our 
surplus
 packs have been taken away behind the hills 3 miles for protection from shell fire.
Entry.250:
hrs rations in our haversack is very hard to live on inthe sun with no protection from it.

Wounded arrive some badly knocked about. Watched the shelling of
Entry.251:
Wed 31st (Continued) A Section Bearers with W.O. 2 M.O's, 1 Padre and 2 sand carts marched out under cover of night to within 1000 yds of our front trenches and under cover of Hill. 18 pdr Battery just behind us and from this Battery and numerous others the shelling was terriffic.

Z7 Redoubt onlyremaining Tk. redoubt of B–h fell at 8 pm.

Thursday 1st

Lay dug in till 
3
pm am. when we moved to main B–h Road. Camels arrived and we began the advance with all other troops along B–h road.

Now in captured territory. Saw terrible effects of our terriffic shell fire. Passed through Beersheebah at 9 a.m. Anzac Med Bgde entered Beersheebah first. Passed through with Turks retreating to 7 miles beyondB–h in direction of B–h Bombed by Tk planes
Entry.252:
Gaza
Hebron Rd. Halted at 11 am. & discovered a concealed Bedouin granit tibbin dump.

Off saddled & halted till midnight

Friday 2nd

2nd L.H. Bgde suffered heavily from Tkaerial torpedoes.

Still 
encamped
 bivouaced.

(Crook. septic hands account for bad writing etc.)

Taubes bombed 4th L.H.F.A. 4 killed, 7 wounded

Return of Bedouins to Beersheebah
Entry.253:
Beersheebah watering and despatchto Hospital which imobile section of 3 LHFA are working in a Tksh building.

Saw Capt. Heath.

Taubes bombed Beersheba again today while we were watering. Thousands of animals are being watered and everything is busy to some orders.

Took snaps round flour mill destroyed by Turks before evacuation.

Some of the wells here are mined. Engineers took cases & cases of explosive from one well alone.

Saw Railway line where the 4th A.L.H. had to make the final charge to route Jacko from Beersheba, across the open about 1000 yds.
Entry.254:
Brigade Orderly despatch.

At 6 p.m. I.C.C. Bgde & Bgde Ammun.Column concentrated at Larykn Caves. 2 Bedouin watering wells close by, to which the Bedouins in Larykn Caves water their flocks & herds.

Reported back to Fd Amb at 10.30 am

2.30 pm Fd Amb moved on to main road & relieved N.Z. L.H.F.A. Mtd Fd Amb at 5 pm when ASec.
Entry.255:
Brigade Orderly despatch till 10.30 am.

At 2.30 pm A.C.F.A moved to main road & relieved N.ZMtd Fd Amb at 4.30 pm when A Sec. moved out at dusk to the front line for active service. I was in the group as advanced dressing station for the 2nd Battn I.C.C. Bgde.

The whole Bgde was completely lost & never got into communication before midnight tonight when N.Z.'s were relieved.

El Jabri
El Hawi
Ras-elNag
Kuteelfah
Entry.256:
At 6 a.m. I.C.C. Battns got a little into touch with each other.

Bombardment by both sides is terrific. Shelling too hot so we moved our position behind some rocks. Not too soon as shells burst wlhere we had been a few minutes before.

Stayed there till 2 pm. when we were relieved by a group from B Section. Instead of traversing the road swept by shell fire to reach our riding camels 2 miles away we made off across the hills. Went 1½ miles & had to return to 2nd Battn as the shell fire was too hot even tlhere. Traversed shell swept road & reached camels at dusk.

Returned to Clearing Station at 6 pm. Prepared a littleto eat & turned in dog tired after the first day of under dinkum shell fire.
Entry.257:
No stand to. What a blessing. Turned out at 6.30 a.m. & 
had a wash
.(First one since over 60 hrs ago) Something to eat, saddle up & off again to the front line to relieve B Section.

This time I was in the group to relieve a B Sec. group with 4th Battn I.C.C. Bgde. 200 yds from our front ridge which is 400 yds from front line Turkish trenches. Continual rifle & machine gun fire overhead. Stray bullets everywhere. 3 pm "Jacko" started shelling our ridge. Dug in under cover of rocks & lay low when the shells whistled, & chanced our luck.

When night fell firing ceased with the exception of the sniping. Turned in at 6 pm wrapped in greatcoat & waterproof sheet.

 an hr's firing from 3 to 4
pm
am and turned in again to be awakened at dawn by the KK & S'pire Batty 

Rained a little at midnight.

Official announced that Gaza & El SherIan have fallen.

Thursday 8 November 1917.

Did an hr's picquet from 3 to 4 am & turned in again to be awakened at dawn by the Kkg & S'pore Batty opening fire on Jacko's gun position.

3 Jackos (
one a German
) gave themselves up at dawn by walking in unarmed to our position on the ridge. All they said to us was "
Mafeesh, imshi
". They looked very frightened & were poorly clad in old Turko-German uniform. Took a snap of them but t'was rather early in the morning for a successful exposure.

Word from Bgde. Hd Qrs of general advance Nth as a lot of the Jackos have "
imsheed
" during the night. 18th Company 4th Battn. advanced on foot on right and left flank of this particular position and were cut up. Some bad cases too. Turkish sniping effective now. 2 chaps near me were sniped and I had to carry a message from the M.O. down a shrapnel swept gully & up a steep ridge under a heavy rifle fire. The narrowest escape I ever hope to have. It was a hot corner. Delivered
Entry.258:
Thursday 8th (Contin'd)
message for 2 stretcher parties. I felt dead beat & winded. Rested ¼ hr and had to lead a cacolet camel with 2 wounded to 
Clearing
Collecting Station. Relieved by B SectionHanded over patients; packed up with full gear and moved off with A.C.F.A. 2 miles closer up than Collecting Station & established Collecting Station there at 5 p.m. Prepared tea of bully & biscuits & turned in after having my septic hands dressed, 1sttime for 
almost
 60 hrs.
Cpl May killed this morng.
Entry.259:
Did an hrs picquet from 3.30 to 4.30 am.

Awakened at dawn by a Taube that dropped 4 bombs on a ridge right close.

Had a shave. 8 days since last shave. Appreciated it too. Saddle up at 8.30 with full gear. This time in the group to relieve B Sec. group at 2nd Battn. I.C.C. advanced dressing station. Things quiet here as "
Jackohas now got the wind up him
". Picquet from 10 pm.

Friday 9th

till 11.30 pm.

Saturday 10
Entry.260:
Notified at 5.45 am that I.C.C. Bgde are being relieved immediately & sent on another stunt towards El Sheria which has fallen. The 2nd Battn. A.D.Stn. detail movement was mixed up with the result that we managed to get to El Sheria at dusk. Filled fantasies, watered camels, rations issued for 5 days stunt. Moved off 3 hrs. later. Saw raily bridge that 
Turks
 our artillery blew up. Moved 6 miles. Slept in greatcoats beside camels till dawn. 
On again till 9 a.m. Halted 3 to 4 hrs & on again in direction of Gaza & coast.

Cpl May killed this morning

Cpl May killed this morning.
Entry.261:
On again till 9 am.Halted 3 to 4 hrs. & then on again in direction of Gaza & coast. An old mail somehow arrived. Letter from Arthur Thompson just in Egypt.

Travelled through till midnight with one stop for 20 mins. and numerous halts 
for 5
 when passing through villages when it was done in single file. 
Line of
 Country looking more settled & civilized. Orchards here & there, owing to war have been neglected.
Entry.262:
In early hours of morning a terrific thunderstorm broke & continued 
till
 for an hr. Ground impassable for camels. Halted till dawn and moved off again till 7.30 a.m. Now camped in an orchard of olive trees etc, 4 miles from the beach and beside the village of Julis. Are now Nth of Gaza.

"Stand to" all night. 
Moved off at dawn in a Nth to NthWest direction

Turks counter attacked strongly at dusk, 14 planes go over on a bomb raiding expedition at 4 pm.

News that (Hebron) El Khalali has fallen.
Entry.263:
Moved off at dawn in a Nth-Nth Westerly direction till 10.30 am. Halted for a rest for camels & a snack for ourselves.

3 miles now from line and our guns & boys are making it hot for "Jacko" on this new front.

Camels watered & fantasies filled. Turks held this position Esdud yesterday morning. 
Left

We left at 3 p.m. and travelled till 
dawn
 dusk almost in sight of the village of Yebna.

"Stand to" all night.
Entry.264:
At 10 am. moved to the foot of the hill on which is the village of Yebna. Given an hrs. leave in the village. At our Collecting Station wounded Turks are 
coming in
 being brought in.

Took snap of 91 Turkish prisoners and a couple of the village.

The oranges we got here are good oh and are a change needed in the diet of bully & biscuits ration.

Got a little rest tonight apart from 40 mins picquet from 11.20 pm to midnight.
Entry.265:
"Stand to" at 3.30 am. A bite to eat & off again at 8 a.m. Passed over a strongly built stone bridge of 3 spans. With one or two halts we reached the village of Akir, taken by the Yoemanry this morning.

Ammunition etc left in Jacko's hasty retreat. Passed near a very"classy village near Abushh. Every building had a red tiled roof & white walls. One building was 3 storey. Gardens & orchards well cultivated.

At Akir our sandcarts took away a number of Turkish wounded prisoners whosewounds were in a shocking condition. On once again & passed through another village on 
the
 a branch railway from Jaffa. Turkish prisoners here also. Some wounded. Travelled till 6 pm. Halted – awaiting orders. Got a little rest.

Ramleh the main Turkish position on the Jaffa-Jerusalem railway has fallen & is now occupied by our troops.
Entry.266:
Stand to at 4 a.m. Something to eat at 6 a.m.

Almost a spell today.

Turned in at 7 a.m. &slept undisturbed till midnight.

Bethleem has fallen
.
Entry.267:
¾ hrs picquet from 2.30 am till 3.15 am. "Stand to" at 4 a.m.

Watered camels at the village of 

Moved out at 10.30 a.m. till in sight of RamlehOff saddled & bivouac
k
ed.
Entry.268:
Moved out at 11 a.m. & travelled through several villages and orchards. The scent of the blossoming hedges is beautiful. The orchards have been well kept & watered.

Bivouacked 2 miles from sea.

(A crook camping ground practically a bed of thistles).

No picquet for me tonight.
Entry.269:
Smith inspected camels. Got rid of my 2 lead camels as result. Moved again at 1 p.m. 5 miles to Surafe
i
nd
a
. Passed through hundreds of acres of well kept orange orchards where hundreds of tons of oranges are going to waste on the trees.

28 days for anyone caught taking oranges & lemons from these orchards.

People in the villages use Engh money and speak Engh language.

A wet night & on picquet. Got drenched.

Tuesday 20
Entry.270:
"Stand to" at4 am (a kind of punishment for not turning out yesterday morning.)

Picquet 6 to 8 am.

Breakfast and started to write letters.

French Jews bring bread, eggs, cake & wine & brandy round on sale to the troops.

Mail to hand. Letters as late as 23rd Sept dated in Australia.

Cold & wet day. Very bleak.

Wrote a letter tonight.
Entry.271: In bivouac. A wet day. Watered camels at village of Richon. A bonzer little joint too. One of Rothchilds villages. French & German Jewish inhabitants carry on with their occupations just the same as ever.
Entry.272:
Went to Ramleh with 15 patients in sitting cacolets to Anzac Receiving Stn. which is in a 
modern
 building of modern architecture & was formerly a church & a hospital.

Had a look through the Mouski. What struck me most was the ancient oil press & Bedouin plough shop where Bedouin plows are made & repaired by ancient methods.

Returned to bivouac at 4.30 p.m.

Moved to new position on advance 5 miles further on the Ramleh-Jaffa road.

Reported to Bgde Hd Qrs as despatch for 24 hrs.

Friday 23 November 1917.

Field Ambulance despatch rider at Brigade Hd Qrs (I.C.C. Bgde). Wrote a few short letters.

(A certain kind of itch is very prevalent in Bgde)

(Found later 
to be
 classed as Camel itch and contagious.)

Saturday 24 November 1917.

In bivouac overlooking Jaffa with Mediterranean Sea in the background.

Moved
 Orderly Room 
orderly
 duties today for our own unit.

Sunday 25 November 1917.

Moved at dawn across Jaffa road 2 miles & bivouaced.

I.C.C. Bgde moved into front trenches. On watering 1/2 way to Jaffa.

Oranges picked off the trees are exceptionally "good". 40 for 3 P.T's I got at one grove which was about the best I have seensofar.

Jews return from Ramleh to Jaffa. From all accounts the Turks gave the Jews a rough time.

Monday 26 November 1917.

On picquet today

2hrs picquet.

Preparations for events expected.

Tuesday 27 November 1917.

Jacko bombed the I.C.C. Brigade today.15 camels killed. 1 man killed and 
3
a number wounded. As many camels were wounded as were killed.

Jacko retook 2 ridges, captured some of the N.Z. Camel Corps 16th Coy 4th Battn. and cut up the troops generally.

Before midnight the N.Z.'s had taken the ridge again.

3 casualties in Fd Amb. (wounded)

Dugouts were then made by the boys at night in case of further visits.

He has the "wind up us" with his Taubes now.

On QM's fatigue 1/2 way to Ramleh during morning.
Entry.273: Taubes also bombed Jaffa, killing and wounding many (Natives only)
Entry.275:
Jacko's over this morning. "Laid no eggs". Apparently recontg.

Hun shelled dump (A.S.C.)

Parcels arrive. None for me.

On picquet at 6 p.m.
Entry.276:
On picquet till 6 pm.

More parcels arrive 
again
. This time 2 for me. One from "home" & one from Joy. Contents very appreciable.

Reinforcements 15 for our unit arrive.

A.S.C. dump shelled again.

Taubes visit us but no bombs dropped.

Watered camels & filled fantasies (in 22 minutes.)

Friday 30
Entry.278:
inch
 5.9 inch Howitzer shells to shell the watering place of the British Yoemanry at 4 pm.

Shells went wide at first and landed short near Hospital tent. Cpl. & W.O. knocked over by concussion of shell.

Village stopped several, killing & wounding 
natives
 bedouin inhabitants.

Shelling ceased at dark.

On picquet at 6 pm.
Entry.279:
"Jacko" came over with 2 Taubes which 2 anti-aircraft guns which our troops brought up during night opened on him. His long range guns then opened all round us. A.S.C. officer killed 2 men 
& 2 camels
 also and 3 wounded. 1 of our camels at the dump killed.

Sent 2 Field Service cards acknowledging receipt of 2 parcels.

On picquet till 6 pm.
Entry.280: Shelled again today but only for 1/2 hr. (Rumored that our 60 pounders got 3 direct hits on one of Jacko's long range guns)These big guns of the enemy are run on rails backwards & forwards thus making it impossible for artillery fire to be effective on them, So the report goes?
Entry.281:
Jacko's long range guns quiet today (18 Coy 4th Batt are to make a raid tonight)

6 p.m saddled up for QM's fatigue to draw rations at new dump 1½ miles along main Jaffa road from position that was shelled the other few days.

Stood to awaiting orders to move to dump. Moved off at 8 pm just as bombardment for raid commenced. Flashes of our artillery lit up the whole country side. No sooner had we arrived at dump than Jacko put the shrapnel & one H.Eshell over us. Had his distance to a yard. He must have a decent spy system.

Threw 30 odd shrapnel shells over & then knocked off. Had an hrs. rest.

Drew rations when motor wagons arrived & started back across the open to our position & travelled till midnight.

Raining with a cold wind.
Entry.282:
Got to our position at 
2 p.m
 2 a.m.

Casualties as result of our raid arriving at ambulance. 40 wounded & 2 killed out of 120 Officers N.C.O's & men. Raid not too successful.

Shelled again today. 1 camel killed in our unit. 6 from other units.

Word of being relieved tonight or in early morning. A certain plan adopted to evade suspicion from enemy observation posts. Successful.

At midnight the NZ's relieved us & Jacko apparently knew nothing of this as not a shell was fired.
Entry.283:
In bivouac 1 mile from main Jaffa road but hardly yet out of range of Jacko's Jack Johnsons 
6
 5.9 inch Howitzer guns, but partly protected by sand dunes right against our position.

Watered camels & filled fantasies at Richon Zion village which is the best village we have come across. People mostly French & well spoken.

Had a look round the shops and bought figs, 
&
 almonds, & bread.

Back to bivouac at 12.15 pm. On picquet from 1 till 2 p.m.

Saddle up (full gear) & moved off at dusk. Travelled to Richon Zion & straight onward & now getting 
well
 away 
at
 fromthe sound of guns etc. A relief too. Travelled till midnight.

Rain started near Yebna.
Entry.284:
Bivouaced at 12.45 am. No stand to. In bivouac 1 mile from village of Yebna. Cold & bleak day. My camel's back crook after last nights movements.

Bgde got lost lastnight and only travelled 8 miles direct although the track they took was about 15 miles. Stayed here 
most of
 the day & tried to move out at night but rain made country impassable.

Ration convoy was lost & rain came on again so Bgde could not move.
Entry.285:
Ration

Rations came up at dawn & were issued
.

Nothing doing today until a party of us were detailed to go back to Julis for rations at dark.

It rained &we were working in mud up to our knees. A fair nightmare altogether.

We were that cold & wet that the Lt. QM. gave us brandy to warm & sort of revive us as we were just about frozen & near collapse.

The camels sent to "our relief" brought in the rations.

This was the roughest night'sspin I have had yet & ever hope to have.

Got back at 3 am. to rest of unit, who had moved 1 mile and then gave up trying to move further tonight. Lay down by a fire we built up to warm ourselves
Entry.286:
Rain eased off.

Moved at 12 noon & travelled to Julius. The last 3 miles was a perfect bog & this with more rain at the time things were interesting.

Today we passed the railhead now at Ashdod.

There is a big Aerodrome at Julius. Counted over 25 planes out. Turkish engine & rolling stock are used on the railway line.

and went to sleep in rain – soaked through & bitterly cold.
Entry.287: Turned out at 6 a.m. Saddle up & on the move once more. "Road" a bit better. Travelled all day with ½ hr for lunch. Bivouaced near Bedouin camp & in the rain. Bitterly cold again.
Entry.288:
December 1917.

Turned out at 5.30 a.m. A mouthful to eat. Saddle up, in full gear and on the trek once more.

Crossed Waddi Guzzi at 11 am - 12
.35
 noon and travelled to camp site near Shellah Junction, where we bivouaced.

Passed enemy fortifications 
near
 used during early part of stunt.

In bivouac at our destination at 3 pm.

What a satisfaction known only to those who came through 
with
 the stunt.
Entry.289:
In a standing camp as it is termed.

A few parades which bore everyone but most Corporals & officers that always glory in same, after some weeks in the firing line.

On a fatigue that will last a day or so. All our sick camels have been taken to Beelah.

("Camel itch" is being fought against now.)
Entry.290:
In a "standing" camp as it is termed. Afew parades today

Still in bivouac.

Published that 10,500 prisoners were taken on this front during November

Heard news of British reverse in France and Italian surrender & reverse on Italian front.
Entry.291:
In bivouac.

Watty & I in the same old bivvy once again.
Entry.292:
In bivouac. Big Xmas Australian mail arrives. I got 27 letters & cards.

The official announcement of the fall of Jerusalem.

Camels taken over from us by C.V.C. natives, so its "finish camels" with us fo a while.

My camel was broken up generally after the stunt and sent away from unit.
Entry.293:
More mail arrives. 6 letters 
I got
 for me.

Messages of congratulation read out on parade at 7 am. today.

Letters dated as late
d
 as Nov 6th in today's mail.

Wrote letters.

Regimental paper the "Cacolet" at last comes to light.

Rumors of a move & of Hollands entrance into war against Engd. News that Clarrie is wounded in France.

(Note.) The mail has cheered everybody & 
wh
 all seem pleased. I got some very nice letters especially from D'nong.
Entry.294:
Things as usual. Rumors of 24 hrs. armistice on all fronts.

Had all our clothes fumigated.

Wrote letters. Everyone in the unit is busy at this. Received 2 letters by mail today.

Moving orders for 20th instto Rafa are to hand for our Bgde.

Pay day. I drew 250 P.T.
Entry.296:
In bivouac. Wrote home tonight. Finished off all old correspondence.

New parcel mail of 6 bags to hand but none for me so far by this mail.
Entry.297:
Advance party leave for new camping site 3 miles N. West of Raf
f
a.

Posted letter to home.

Camel inspection by Brigadier General Smith, mainly for counting Nos. of camels in Bgde. A farce too.

Thursday 20
Entry.298:
In a 
camp
 at last (
for a spell
.) at Rafa.
Entry.302:
In camp

Boys merry with liquor tonight.
Entry.303:
Christmas Day on active service. (In a camp for a rest at some distance behind the firing line at RAFA.)

Spent a decent Xmas day.

Boys merry again with liquor.
Entry.304: A lovely day today –resembling an Australian Spring day in Gipps'd.
Entry.306: In camp. Football matches played on the flat near Sand Dunes.
Entry.307:
Football matches. Rugby & Soccer played.

Sunday 30
Entry.308:
Sunday as usual in a camp.

Arnold & Phillips go on leave to Cairo.
Entry.309: New Years Eve, and still in a rest camp. A spree, concert, etc (beer, wisky, rum & gin for everyone who cared for it, during the evening. Things were merry & a good number including myself saw the Old Year out and the New Year in.
